THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Timothy Mills,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Gary E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25864
Heard April 21, 2004 - Filed September 
  7, 2004Â 

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey and Assistant Appellate 
  Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, 
  of Columbia, for appellant.
Deputy Director Teresa A. Knox, Tommy Evans, Jr., and J. 
  Benjamin Aplin, all of South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole & 
  Pardon Services, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This is a statutory construction case.Â  The 
  sole issue before us is the application ofÂ  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-560(D) (Supp. 
  2003) which determines the sentence for successive revocations of a prisonerâ€™s 
  community supervision.Â  We affirm the trial judgeâ€™s reading of the statute and 
  the sentence imposed.Â  
FACTS
Appellant pled guilty to distribution of crack cocaine, second offense, and 
  was sentenced to six months imprisonment.Â  He was given credit for two days 
  served.Â  After serving five months and two days, he entered a Community Supervision 
  Program (CSP) which was to continue for two years.Â  
This case was commenced when appellantâ€™s supervising 
  agent swore out a warrant alleging numerous violations of CSP including failure 
  to report, use of controlled substances, failure to maintain employment, and 
  failure to pay supervision fees.Â  The trial judge revoked appellantâ€™s CSP and 
  sentenced him to five months and seven days.Â  Because this was the second time 
  appellantâ€™s CSP was revoked, his sentence was determined under Â§ 24-21-560(D).
Appellant claims Â§ 24-21-560(D) limits his sentence 
  for revocation to the remaining time left on his original sentence for the substantive 
  crime.Â  His original sentence was six months, of which he served five months 
  and two days, and he served three weeks on the prior revocation.Â  Appellant 
  contends his revocation sentence therefore should not exceed five days.Â  He 
  complains the trial judge erroneously interpreted Â§ 24-21-560(D) to allow a 
  revocation sentence that was â€œalmost doubleâ€ his original sentence.
DISCUSSION
Under Â§ 24-21-560(A), participation in CSP is a mandatory condition of release 
  for most no-parole offenses. [1] Â  
  Section 24-21-560 further provides in pertinent part:

(C) If the department determines 
  that a prisoner has violated a term of the community supervision program and 
  the community supervision should be revoked, a probation agent must initiate 
  a proceeding in General Sessions Court.Â  
. . . .
If the court determines 
  that a prisoner has wilfully violated a term or condition of the community supervision 
  program, the court may impose any other terms or conditions considered appropriate 
  and may continue the prisoner on community supervision, or the court may revoke 
  the prisoner's community supervision and impose a sentence of up to one year 
  for violation of the community supervision program. . . .
(D) If a prisoner's community supervision is revoked by 
  the court and the court imposes a period of incarceration for the revocation, 
  the prisoner also must complete a community supervision program of up to two 
  years as determined by the department pursuant to subsection (B) when he is 
  released from incarceration.
A prisoner who is sentenced for successive revocations of the 
  community supervision program may be required to serve terms of incarceration 
  for successive revocations, as provided in Section 24-21-560(C), and may be 
  required to serve additional periods of community supervision for successive 
  revocations, as provided in Section 24-21-560(D).Â  The maximum aggregate 
  amount of time the prisoner may be required to serve when sentenced for successive 
  revocations may not exceed an amount of time equal to the length of incarceration 
  imposed for the original "no parole offense".Â  The original term 
  of incarceration does not include any portion of a suspended sentence.

(emphasis added).Â  Appellant contends the underscored language 
  means his sentence for revocation can equal only the amount of unserved time 
  remaining on his original sentence.Â  This construction of Â§ 24-21-560(D) is 
  not supported by a plain reading of the statute.
Although a penal statute must be strictly construed 
  against the State, when the terms of the statute are clear and unambiguous, 
  we are constrained to give them their literal meaning.Â  State v. Blackmon, 
  304 S.C. 270, 403 S.E.2d 660 (1991).Â  The words of the statute must be given 
  their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction 
  to limit or expand the statute's operation.Â  Brown v. State, 343 S.C. 
  342, 540 S.E.2d 849 (2001).
Subsection (C) of Â§ 24-21-560
provides that â€œthe court may revoke the prisonerâ€™s community supervision and
impose a sentence of up to one year for a violation of the community supervision program.â€Â  Subsection 
  (D) then provides that for a successive revocation, the prisoner may 
  be sentenced â€œas provided in [subsection] (C)â€ i.e., for up to one year, 
  with the limitation that the total time imposed â€œfor successive revocationsâ€ 
  i.e., all revocations, cannot exceed the length of time of the 
  prisonerâ€™s original sentence.Â  Subsection (D) does not provide, as appellant 
  contends, that the sentence for any successive revocation is limited to the 
  amount of time remaining on the prisonerâ€™s original sentence, nor does this 
  statute inevitably result in the â€œdoublingâ€ of a prisonerâ€™s sentence.Â  Further, 
  we emphasize that the only issue before us is the construction of this particular 
  statute and not the wisdom of the CSP statutory scheme as a whole. 
  [2] 
Since appellant served three weeks on his prior revocation, 
  and his time for all revocations cannot exceed six months, the trial judge properly 
  sentenced appellant to five months and seven days.
 AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  
  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  The majority holds that 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-560 (Supp. 2003) permits an inmate found to have violated 
  the terms of his community supervision program (CSP) to serve an additional 
  sentence, [3]  up to an amount equal to the 
  period of incarceration imposed as part his original sentence.Â  I would read 
  the statute differently
CSP â€œserves essentially the same function for persons convicted of 
  â€˜no parole offensesâ€™ as parole does for other inmates.â€Â  Jackson v. State, 
  349 S.C. 62, 562 S.E.2d 475 (2002).Â  As with parole, the Department of Probation, 
  Parole, and Pardon Services (DPPPS) sets the initial length, [4]  terms, and conditions of CSP, 
  and determines whether violations have occurred, and initiates a judicial revocation 
  process.Â  If the circuit court judge determines the inmate has willfully violated 
  the terms of his CSP, then the judge has three options:Â  1) continue the CSP; 
  2) continue the CSP but alter the terms and conditions; or 3) revoke CSP and 
  order the inmate reincarcerated.Â  The statute limits the total amount of prison 
  time an inmate can serve following CSP revocation(s) to the period of incarceration 
  ordered by the sentencing judge.Â  Read literally, then, I agree with the majority 
  that the statute permits appellant to be reincarcerated for another six months, 
  the â€œlength of incarceration imposed for the original â€˜no parole offense.â€™â€
In my opinion, however, to read the statute literally is to render 
  it unconstitutional.Â  Compare In re Luckabaugh, 351 S.C. 122, 
  568 S.E.2d 338 (2002) (no double jeopardy or due process violation in involuntary 
  commitment for sexually violent predators because commitment is not penal).Â  
  An inmateâ€™s original â€˜no paroleâ€™ sentence ordinarily contains a period of incarceration 
  plus a suspended portion. Section 24-21-560 (D) limits the maximum period 
  of reincarceration for CSP revocations to â€œan amount equal to the length of 
  incarceration imposed for the original â€˜no parole offenseâ€™â€.Â  The original term 
  of incarceration does not include any portion of a suspended sentence.â€Â  In 
  order to avoid any constitutional infirmity, I would read this language as putting 
  an outside limit on incarceration of twice the period imposed by the trial judge.Â  
  The outside limit on the total amount of time an inmate could be incarcerated 
  and/or required to participate in the CSP program is the length of the original 
  sentence, that is, the term of incarceration plus any period of suspension.Â  
  For example, an individual sentenced to 20 years, suspended on service of seven 
  years, would be subject to serving an additional seven years for CSP violations, [5]  but in no case could be held 
  in prison or required to participate in a CSP program after the expiration of 
  the 20 years.Â  Here, appellant received a six-month sentence, no part of which 
  was suspended.Â  In my view, the maximum time he could constitutionally be subjected 
  to incarceration and/or required to participate in the CSP program pursuant 
  to this sentence was six months.Â  That period having expired, I would hold the 
  trial court erred in reincarcerating
appellant.       

 
   [1] Distribution 
    of crack cocaine, second offense, is a â€œno parole offense.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
    Â§ 24-13-100 (Supp. 2003).Â  

 
   [2] See 
    State v. Dawkins, 352 S.C. 162, 167, 573 S.E.2d 783, 785 (2002) (construing 
    CSP statutes and noting that â€œall parties agree the statutory scheme is convoluted.â€)
    
  
  

 
   [3]  This is the term used in Â§ 24-21-560; if the revocation 
    judge is truly imposing a new sentence of up to one year, then the protections 
    afforded all criminal defendants, including but not limited to the right to 
    an indictment, counsel, and a jury, must be afforded her.Â  None of these constitutional 
    niceties were afforded appellant, or any of the other CSP violators who have 
    come before the Court.Â  Our obligation to construe statutes as constitutional 
    where possible, e.g. Ward v. State, 343 S.C. 14, 538 S.E.2d 
    245 (2000), is a driving force behind my construction of Â§ 24-21-560.

 
   [4]  The maximum period of CSP is two years. 

 
   [5]  Of course, an inmate is subject to a maximum one 
    year period of incarceration each time he is found to have willfully violated 
    CSP, but each reincarceration is followed by another CSP until the program 
    is successfully completed or until the term of the original sentence is met.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
James G. Blakely, a.k.a. Jimmy Gatewood Blakely,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina,       
        Petitioner.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
Joseph J. Watson, Circuit Court Judge

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Opinion No. 25865
Submitted June 23, 2004 - Filed September 
  7, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Chief, Capital & Collateral Litigation 
  Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salle W. Elliott, and Assistant 
  Attorney General Christopher L. Newton, all of Columbia, for petitioner.
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Haile, of Columbia, 
  for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition to review the grant 
  of relief in this post-conviction relief (PCR) action.Â  The PCR judge found 
  counsel was ineffective for failing to object to evidence of respondentâ€™s previous 
  threats.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Respondent was charged with murder and assault and 
  battery with intent to kill (ABIK) for wounding his girlfriend Sarah Ann Moss 
  (a.k.a. â€œAnnâ€) and killing her friend John Henderson (a.k.a. â€œSteveâ€) after 
  a domestic dispute earlier in the day.Â  Respondent shot both victims in front 
  of Annâ€™s house as they were getting out of a car.Â  Steve managed to drive off 
  after being shot but was found dead near his car about a half-mile away.Â  
Respondent claimed self-defense on the murder charge.Â  
  He testified he saw Steve and Ann kissing in the car.Â  When he confronted them, 
  Steve came at respondent with a knife.Â  To the contrary, eye-witnesses testified 
  they saw Steve put his hands up immediately before being shot.Â  No one saw a 
  knife and no knife was ever found at the scene or in Steveâ€™s car.Â  In his statement 
  to police, respondent did not mention that Steve had a knife when respondent 
  shot him.Â  Respondent claimed he told detectives about the knife but they omitted 
  it from his statement.Â  
As a defense to ABIK, respondent testified he accidentally 
  shot Ann when she came up behind him after he shot Steve.Â  
The jury found respondent guilty of the lesser offenses of voluntary manslaughter 
  and assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  He was given consecutive 
  sentences of thirty years and ten years.Â  Respondentâ€™s direct appeal was dismissed 
  after an Anders review.Â  He then filed this action for PCR.
ISSUE

Was counsel ineffective for not objecting to evidence of previous threats?

DISCUSSION
On direct examination, Ann testified as follows:

Q:Â Â Â Â Â  What was your relationship with [respondent]?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  I was his girlfriend.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  How long did yâ€™all date?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  About six months.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Were you dating that day on January 1st, 1998?Â  Were yâ€™all 
  still dating then?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  No. We had quit.Â  I had been calling the relationship all along 
  off, and he like kept threatening me.Â  And, you know, threatened to do something 
  to my family like killing us and blowing up the house.Â  And so I kind of like 
  hung in there because I was afraid of him.

The PCR judge found counsel should have objected to this evidence of previous 
  threats because it impermissibly placed respondentâ€™s character in issue.Â  
It is well-settled that evidence of previous threats by the defendant 
  is admissible to show malice.Â  State v. Lee, 255 S.C. 309, 178 S.E.2d 
  652 (1971); see also State v. Alford, 264 S.C. 26, 212 S.E.2d 
  252 (1975) (previous threats against companion of victim at time of assault 
  also admissible).Â  Respondent was charged with murder and ABIK, both of which 
  include the element of malice.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-10 (1985) (murder is killing 
  of any person with malice aforethought); State v. Sutton, 340 S.C. 393, 
  532 S.E.2d 283 (2000) (ABIK is an unlawful act of violent injury to person of 
  another with malice aforethought).Â  Further, under Rule 404(b), SCRE, this evidence 
  is admissible as evidence of intent.Â  
We conclude counsel was not ineffective for failing to object to the evidence 
  of previous threats.Â  Accordingly, the grant of relief is
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT, and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Medical University of South Carolina,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Dr. Philippe Arnaud,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25866
Heard June 23, 2004 - Filed September 
  7, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Francis T. Draine, of Columbia, for appellant.
Stephen L. Brown, Nancy Bloodgood, and Carol B. Ervin, of Young, Clement, Rivers 
  & Tisdale, L.L.P., of Charleston, for respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Respondent (MUSC) filed a breach 
  of contract and declaratory judgment action against appellant (Dr. Arnaud) following 
  Dr. Arnaudâ€™s refusal to leave his employment.Â  The trial court granted MUSCâ€™s 
  motion for summary judgment.Â  After certifying this case from the Court of Appeals 
  pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, we affirm.
FACTS
Dr. Arnaud entered into an Agreement of Resignation (agreement) with MUSC in 
  July 1998.Â  In this agreement, Dr. Arnaud agreed to irrevocably resign his employment 
  with MUSCâ€™s Department of Immunology and Microbiology as of June 30, 2002, in 
  exchange for a ten percent increase in his base salary for the fiscal years 
  of 1998/1999, 1999/2000, 2000/2001, and 2001/2002.Â  No attempt was made to modify 
  the agreement after signing.
In August 2001, Dr. Arnaud attended a seminar concerning the Teacher 
  and Employee Retention Incentive (TERI) program.Â  Dr. Arnaudâ€™s impression after 
  the seminar was that if he entered TERI, his participation in the program would 
  give him the right to keep his position at MUSC. [1] 
As of October 1, 2001, Dr. Arnaud entered the TERI program, which 
  did not affect his job in any manner.Â  The Dean of MUSC wrote Dr. Arnaud a letter 
  on October 22 informing him that, although he had entered the TERI program, 
  he would still have to retire at the end of June 2002 pursuant to his agreement 
  with MUSC. [2] Â  Joe Good, General 
  Counsel to MUSC, wrote a letter to Dr. Arnaud on December 10, 2001.Â  In this 
  letter, Good indicated that Dr. Arnaudâ€™s TERI participation would not alter 
  the prior agreement and that Dr. Arnaudâ€™s employment would terminate in June 
  2002.Â  However, in April 2002, counsel for Dr. Arnaud sent a letter to Good 
  stating that Dr. Arnaud was entitled to work at MUSC for another five years 
  from the date he entered the TERI program. [3] 
During his deposition, Dr. Arnaud gave inconsistent testimony.Â  
  He testified Good told him TERI superseded the agreement and that he could continue 
  to work under TERI.Â  However, he also testified he was not told by anyone that 
  TERI would supersede his agreement.Â  Specifically, Dr. Arnaud acknowledged that 
  no one in his department had informed him that after he entered TERI, his previous 
  agreement was no longer in effect and that he would be guaranteed a job for 
  five years if he signed up for TERI.Â  Dr. Arnaud stated that Good, the counsel 
  for MUSC, told him resignation agreements could be changed and new agreements 
  could be entered into, but, he acknowledged, counsel was not specifically talking 
  about his agreement.Â  Dr. Arnaud testified Good told him that, even though the 
  agreement did not mention TERI, he could join TERI.Â  Dr. Arnaud acknowledged 
  that Good did not tell him he did not have to resign in June 2002.
Holly Maben, the benefits coordinator of MUSC, gave an affidavit 
  in which she stated she told Dr. Arnaud the agreement controlled over his TERI 
  application and he would have to terminate his employment on June 30, 2002, 
  despite his TERI participation.Â  She stated he was given five years on the TERI 
  application only so he could continue TERI participation if he decided to work 
  for another state employer when he left MUSC. 
  [4] 
The trial court found MUSC was entitled to summary judgment on its 
  breach of contract claim and was entitled to specific performance in the form 
  of Dr. Arnaudâ€™s immediate resignation.Â  The court further found, pursuant to 
  the declaratory judgment action, that Â§ 9-1-2210(A) does not alter a state employeeâ€™s 
  underlying employment rights or grant any additional employment rights to the 
  employee while that employee participates in the TERI program.
ISSUE

Did the trial court err by granting summary judgment to MUSC?

DISCUSSION
Summary judgment is appropriate only if there is no genuine issue 
  of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of 
  law.Â  Cunningham ex rel. Grice v. Helping Hands, Inc., 352 S.C. 485, 
  575 S.E.2d 549 (2003).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist 
  for summary judgment purposes, the evidence and all the inferences that can 
  be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.Â  Id.
Dr. Arnaudâ€™s contention that the court improperly granted summary 
  judgment by ignoring disputed issues of material fact is without merit because 
  any alleged disputed issues of fact exist solely due to Dr. Arnaudâ€™s own inconsistent 
  statements in his deposition.Â  Dr. Arnaud testified MUSCâ€™s counsel, Good, did 
  not tell him he did not have to resign June 30, 2002, i.e. that 
  the previous resignation agreement was nullified by participation in the TERI 
  program.Â  He also stated that no one told him participation in TERI would 
  override the agreement.Â  However, he also testified at various times that Good 
  told him that entering in the TERI program superseded his previous agreement 
  and that he could continue to work under TERI.
Given Dr. Arnaudâ€™s vacillation, his mere allegation that he was informed TERI 
  superseded the agreement is not enough to survive a summary judgment motion.Â  
  See City of Columbia v. Town of Irmo, 316 S.C. 193, 447 S.E.2d 
  855 (1994) (opposing party may not rest upon mere allegations, but must respond 
  with specific facts showing genuine issue).Â  All that was presented to the trial 
  court was Dr. Arnaudâ€™s bare assertion that he had been informed TERI nullified 
  his previous agreement.Â  In fact, the evidence is clear Dr. Arnaud was informed 
  several times that he was expected to honor the agreement even though he had 
  entered the TERI program. [5] 
Accordingly, the trial court did not err by granting summary judgment 
  in favor of MUSC. [6] Â  See 
  Cunningham ex rel. Grice v. Helping Hands, Inc., supra (summary 
  judgment appropriate only if no genuine issue of material fact and moving party 
  entitled to judgment as matter of law).Â  The remaining two issues raised by 
  Dr. Arnaud are deemed abandoned given the arguments on those issues were conclusory.Â  
  See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 444 S.E.2d 513 (1994) 
  (failure to provide arguments or supporting authority for an issue renders it 
  abandoned).
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Pertinent portions of the TERI 
    guidelines for state government state:Â  (1) â€œParticipants in the TERI program 
    retain the same status and employment rights they held upon entering the program;â€ 
    (2) â€œWhile program participants retain the same rights to their positions 
    they held prior to entering the program, participation in the TERI program 
    does not guarantee employment for the specified program period;â€ and (3) â€œEmployees 
    who enter the TERI program gain no new employment rights and are subject to 
    the employment policies and procedures associated with whatever position(s) 
    they occupy during the program period, to include those policies and procedures 
    related to salary, benefits, and grievance rights.â€Â  See also S.C. 
    Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-2210 (Supp. 2003).

 
   [2] This 
    letter was in response to Dr. Arnaudâ€™s letter requesting the Deanâ€™s approval 
    of his entrance into the TERI program and indicating his plan to remain at 
    MUSC until 2005.Â  His letter did not reference the earlier resignation agreement.

 
   [3]  MUSC sent appellant two more 
    letters.Â  The first letter indicated Dr. Arnaudâ€™s resignation was effective 
    June 30, 2002.Â  The second letter, dated July 1, 2002, instructed Dr. Arnaud 
    to return his identification badge and any keys to the departmental space 
    he held and to remove all personal items from his office.

 
   [4] The 
    affidavit of Peggy Boykin, the director of the South Carolina State Retirement 
    System, was also submitted.Â  In this affidavit, Boykin, who was involved in 
    the drafting of the TERI legislation, gave opinions regarding what the TERI 
    legislation was and was not intended for.Â  Boykin also gave specific opinions 
    regarding how the TERI legislation applied to Dr. Arnaudâ€™s situation.

 
   [5] We note that while the affidavit 
    of Peggy Boykin, the director of the South Carolina State Retirement System, 
    was also submitted, this affidavit is not admissible as evidence of legislative 
    intent.Â  See Kennedy v. South Carolina Retirement Sys., 345 
    S.C. 339, 549 S.E.2d 243 (2001) (it is a settled principle in the interpretation 
    of statutes that even where there is some ambiguity or some uncertainty in 
    the language used, resort cannot be had to the opinions of legislators or 
    of others concerned in the enactment of the law, for the purpose of ascertaining 
    the intent of the legislature).Â  Therefore, the trial court should not have 
    considered this affidavit when deciding to grant summary judgment to MUSC.

 
   [6] Dr. Arnaud further argues the 
    court erred by deciding the novel issue of the statutory construction of a 
    state employeeâ€™s retirement rights in a summary judgment proceeding.Â  However, 
    the mere fact a case involves a novel issue does not render summary judgment 
    inappropriate.Â  ML-Lee Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 
    320 S.C. 143, 463 S.E.2d 618 (Ct. App. 1995), revâ€™d in part on other grounds, 
    327 S.C. 238, 489 S.E.2d 470 (1997).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Edward Huggler,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State of South Carolina,       
Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Lancaster County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Trial Judge
Kenneth G. Goode, Post-Conviction Relief 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25867
Submitted June 23, 2004 - Filed September 
  7, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Chief, Capital and Collateral Litigation Donald J. 
  Zelenka, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Allen Bullard, and Assistant Attorney 
  General David Spencer, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Edward Huggler (Respondent) 
  was convicted of two counts of criminal sexual conduct with a minor and sentenced 
  to concurrent sentences of nine years for each count. [1] Â  Respondent appealed and the 
  court of appeals dismissed the case.Â  State v. Huggler, 98-UP-492 (S.C. 
  Ct. App. filed November 9, 1998).Â  Respondent applied for post-conviction relief 
  (PCR).Â  After a hearing, the PCR judge found that trial counsel was ineffective 
  for (1) failing to object to the admission of written statements given by the 
  victims to the police, describing the sexual abuse and (2) failing to conduct 
  a meaningful cross-examination of the testifying victims.Â  Accordingly, the 
  PCR judge granted a new trial.Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition for certiorari 
  and now reverse.Â Â Â Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
Mother 
  [2]  invited 33-year-old Edward Huggler (Respondent) to live with her and 
  her family in order to help out with transportation and childcare.Â  Respondent 
  was a friend of Motherâ€™s brother and, at the time, Respondent had no place to 
  live.Â  Also living with Mother were her mother, her husband, 14-year-old daughter 
  Jane, 10-year-old son John, and 12-year-old stepdaughter Jill. 
One afternoon, when Respondent was watching 
  the children, the children, Respondent, and Janeâ€™s friend Lisa [3]  began to play a game of â€œtruth or dare.â€Â  Although 
  the game began with innocent dares, the dares eventually became sexual in nature.Â  
  Lisa testified that Jane â€œsucked [Respondentâ€™s] private part,â€ and then Jane 
  dared Lisa to do the same.Â  Lisa declined and then Jane dared Jill to do it, 
  and she did.Â  Lisa also testified that â€œ[Respondent] licked Janeâ€™s private part.â€
Jane also testified as to what happened 
  during the game.Â  Jane testified that the game first became sexual with dares 
  including kisses on the cheek and french kissing.Â  Later, the dares involved 
  oral sex and were carried out in the bathroom, with all the children present.Â  
  After one of the â€œroundsâ€ in the bathroom, Respondent and the children returned 
  to the living room, and Respondent asked Jill â€œto do something about a man in 
  a boat.â€Â  Respondent then began masturbating himself, and Jill masturbated herself 
  as well.
John, Janeâ€™s 10-year-old brother, testified 
  that Respondent dared John to â€œmoonâ€ Lisa, and John did so.Â  He also testified 
  that Respondent â€œmade Jane and Jill suck [Respondentâ€™s] private parts.â€Â  Finally, 
  John testified that he did not engage in sexual activity with Respondent.Â Â Â Â  

Lastly, Jill, who is John and Janeâ€™s stepsister 
  and who lived with them at the time, testified that the game went from dares 
  of kissing to â€œeating each other out.â€Â  She also testified that Respondent bit 
  her breast.
The â€œgameâ€ ended when Mother returned 
  home.Â  The front door was locked, so Mother knocked on the window, asking â€œWhy 
  canâ€™t I get in?â€Â  The children did not tell Mother why the door was locked or 
  about what had happened while she was away.Â  Soon thereafter, Respondent moved 
  out, and eventually the children told Mother about the sexual activity with 
  Respondent.Â  Mother contacted the police.
The police took written statements from 
  all three children. [4] Â  In their 
  written statements, the children detailed sexual acts that they engaged in with 
  Respondent.Â  During trial, each of these written statements was entered into 
  evidence, and defense counsel affirmatively stated, each time, that he did not 
  object to the statementsâ€™ admission.Â  In addition, defense counsel did not cross-examine 
  John or Jill. [5] Â  Counsel did, however, cross-examine Lisa and 
  Jane.Â  
After the State finished presenting its 
  case, defense counsel announced that he was not presenting any witnesses, including 
  Respondent, and requested thirty minutesâ€”instead of fifteen minutes, as the 
  judge offeredâ€”to give his closing argument.Â  In closing, defense counsel presented 
  a chart outlining the inconsistencies between the childrenâ€™s live testimonies 
  and their written statements.Â  In addition, he argued that the State failed 
  to adequately investigate the case.Â  Finally, he argued that the children made 
  up the allegations to get out of trouble for smoking cigarettes.
The jury found Respondent guilty on two 
  counts of criminal sexual conduct with a minor, and he was sentenced to nine 
  years imprisonment for each count, to be served concurrently.Â  After his appeal 
  was dismissed, Respondent applied for PCR, and on October 17, 2000, a hearing 
  was held.Â  Defense counsel did not attend the hearing. [6] Â  Although the PCR judge left the record open so that defense 
  counsel could be deposed at a later date, defense counsel was never located, 
  and his deposition was never taken. 
At the hearing, PCR counsel argued that defense 
  counsel â€œfell below the standardâ€ by allowing the childrenâ€™s written statements 
  to be admitted into evidence without adequately cross-examining the children 
  when they were on the witness stand.Â  PCR counsel further argued that the written 
  statements improperly bolstered the childrenâ€™s testimony on direct.Â  If it were 
  not for this â€œfatal flaw,â€ PCR counsel argued, there was â€œa reasonable possibility 
  that the jury could have reached a different verdict had the case been tried 
  correctly.â€Â  
The PCR judge agreed and granted relief based, 
  in part, on the following rationale:Â  

This Court has great concerns that [Respondentâ€™s] attorney 
  agreed or otherwise did not speak against the introduction of the three statements.Â  
  Normally statements of witnesses are not allowed into evidence, they not being 
  confessions of the [Respondent].Â  Also, normally juries have to decide verdicts 
  from their oral remembrance, not a writing that bolsters one side.

Moreover, the PCR judge stated:

To forego cross-examination of any witness and let the same 
  witnessâ€™ statement be admitted into evidence is not effective representation.Â  
  To challenge credibility in closing argument without any cross-examination to 
  establish inconsistencies is not effective representation and not trial strategy.

This Court granted the Stateâ€™s 
  petition for certiorari, and the State now raises the following issue for review:

Did the PCR judge err in finding counsel ineffective?

Law/Analysis
Standard of Review
This Court gives great deference to the PCR courtâ€™s findings 
  of fact and conclusions of law. Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 
  525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000) (citing McCray v. State, 317 S.C. 557, 455 
  S.E.2d 686 (1995)).Â  On review, a PCR judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld if there 
  is any evidence of probative value sufficient to support them.Â  Cherry v. 
  State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).Â  If no probative evidence 
  exists to support the findings, this Court will reverse.Â  Pierce v. State, 
  338 S.C. 139, 144, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000) (citing Holland v. State, 
  322 S.C. 111, 470 S.E.2d 378 (1996)).
Discussion
The State argues that the PCR court erred in finding counsel 
  ineffective.Â  We agree.
To establish a claim that counsel was ineffective, a PCR 
  applicant must show that (1) counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective 
  standard of reasonableness and (2) but for counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable 
  probability that the outcome of the trial would have been different. Strickland 
  v. Washington, 466 U.S. 688, 104 S. Ct. 2052 (1984); Johnson v. State, 
  325 S.C. 182, 186, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997).Â  â€œA reasonable probability is 
  a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcomeâ€ of the trial.Â  
  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 694, 104 S. Ct. at 2068.Â  
When reviewing a counselâ€™s performance, there is a strong 
  presumption that counsel â€œrendered adequate assistance and made all significant 
  decisions in the exercise of reasonable professional judgment.â€Â  Strickland, 
  466 U.S. at 690, 104 S. Ct. at 2066.Â  Consequently, courts apply a â€œhighly deferentialâ€ 
  standard of review.Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 689, 104 S. Ct. at 2065.Â  
  Counsel may avoid a finding of ineffectiveness if he articulates a valid reason 
  for using a certain strategy.Â  Ingle v. State, 348 S.C. 467, 470, 560 
  S.E.2d 401, 402 (2002) (citations omitted).Â  Counselâ€™s strategy will be reviewed 
  under â€œan objective standard of reasonableness.â€ Id.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In the present case, the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that defense 
  counsel rendered ineffective assistance was based on two grounds:Â  (1) defense 
  counsel erred by not objecting to, or otherwise speaking out against, the admission 
  of the witnessesâ€™ written statements that were taken by the police during the 
  investigation; and (2) defense counsel failed to adequately cross-examine the 
  victims.Â  In sum, the PCR judge had â€œgreat concernâ€ that counsel allowed the 
  written statements to be admitted and found that it was not â€œtrial strategyâ€ 
  for defense counsel to argue inconsistencies between the written statements 
  and the testimonies during closing; instead, such inconsistencies should have 
  been highlighted during cross-examination. 
  [7] Â  Â Â 
First, as to counselâ€™s failure to object to the admission 
  of the victimsâ€™ written statements, we find that even though the statements 
  likely constituted inadmissible hearsay and were improperly admitted, the outcome 
  of Respondentâ€™s case was not prejudiced by their admission.Â Â  
The rule against hearsay prohibits the admission of out-of-court 
  statements used to prove the truth of the matter asserted unless an exception 
  to the rule applies.Â  Dawkins v. State, 346 S.C. 151, 156, 551 S.E.2d 
  260, 262 (2001) (citing Jolly v. State, 314 S.C. 17, 443 S.E.2d 566 (1994)).Â  
  A well-settled exception in criminal sexual conduct cases allows the admission 
  of limited corroborative testimony.Â  Id.Â  When the victim testifies and 
  is subject to cross-examination, the victimâ€™s prior consistent statement is 
  admissible and is not hearsay, provided the statement is limited to the 
  time and place of the incident. Rule 801(d)(1)(D), SCRE; State v. Jeffcoat, 
  350 S.C. 392, 395-396, 565 S.E.2d 321, 323 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Therefore, when 
  a victim testifies and is subject to cross-examination, the details of the victimâ€™s 
  complaint or report are not admissible.Â  State v. Cox, 274 S.C. 624, 
  627-628, 266 S.E.2d 784, 786 (1980).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the present case, the police obtained written statements 
  from each of the three child witnesses, recounting, in detail, the sexual activity 
  that occurred with Respondent.Â  After each witness testified on direct, the 
  State introduced the witnessâ€™s corresponding written statement into evidence, 
  and defense counsel affirmatively stated that he did not object.Â  Because the 
  victims testified and were subject to cross, and because the victimsâ€™ written 
  statements went beyond describing the time and place of the incident, the statements 
  constituted inadmissible hearsay.Â  Therefore, defense counselâ€™s failure to object 
  to their introduction fell below an objective standard of reasonableness.Â  Dawkins, 
  346 S.C. at 156, 551 S.E.2d at 263; but see Sanchez v. State, 
  351 S.C. 270, 569 S.E.2d 363 (2002) (Burnett & Toal, JJ., dissenting) (noting 
  that there are circumstances where it may be reasonable trial strategy for counsel 
  to decline to object to inadmissible hearsay testimony in a case involving criminal 
  sexual conduct).Â Â  
But given that the witnessesâ€™ testimonies on direct provided 
  overwhelming evidence that sexual abuse did in fact occur, counselâ€™s failure 
  to object to the admission of the written statements did not prejudice the outcome 
  of Respondentâ€™s case.Â  The evidence of abuse was overwhelming even without the 
  content in the written statements.Â Â Â Â Â  
Second, as to counselâ€™s failure to adequately cross-examine 
  the child victims, we find that the inconsistencies between the testimony and 
  the written statements were not substantial enough to warrant a cross-examination 
  beyond that which defense counsel conducted.Â Â Â Â  
All of the children who participated in the â€œgameâ€ testified 
  and were subject to cross-examination.Â  Counsel cross-examined two of the four 
  witnesses.Â  During cross, counsel did not focus on the inconsistencies between 
  the direct testimonies and the written statements; instead counsel raised the 
  inconsistencies in his closing argument.Â  The gist of counselâ€™s closing argument 
  was that the written statements were more descriptive than the live testimonies 
  (and vice versa), and therefore the witnesses lacked credibility.Â  After reviewing 
  each of the inconsistencies cited by counsel in closing, we find that the inconsistencies 
  were insignificant, relating, for example, to the number of times a particular 
  sexual act occurred or whether it occurred in the bathroom or in the living 
  room.Â  Therefore, it may have been reasonable for counsel to highlight the inconsistencies 
  in closing rather than attempt to use them for impeachment purposes.Â  Moreover, 
  given that this was a sexual abuse case involving children, it may have been 
  prudent for counsel to limit cross-examination to the issues he thought were 
  most important, without picking apart the witnessesâ€™ testimonies based on meaningless 
  inconsistencies.Â  
Nonetheless, because we do not have the benefit of counselâ€™s 
  testimony as to why he limited cross and instead raised the inconsistencies 
  during closing, we cannot scrutinize counselâ€™s trial strategy.Â  As a result, 
  we focus on whether counselâ€™s assistance prejudiced Respondentâ€™s case as required 
  under Strickland v. Washington.Â  In light of the overwhelming evidence 
  presented by the State, namely the live, consistent testimonies of four witnesses 
  who testified, in detail, that sexual abuse occurred, and our findings that 
  (1) Respondentâ€™s case was not prejudiced by the admission of the witnessesâ€™ 
  written statements, and (2) counselâ€™s decision to attack witness credibility 
  in closing rather than in cross does not, on its face, constitute error, we 
  find that there is not a â€œreasonable probabilityâ€ that but for counselâ€™s error, 
  the outcome of Respondentâ€™s case would have been different.Â  Strickland, 
  466 U.S. at 694, 104 S. Ct. at 2068.
Conclusion
Because there is no evidence of probative value sufficient 
  to support the PCR courtâ€™s finding that counsel was ineffective, the PCR courtâ€™s 
  decision is REVERSED.Â  
MOORE, WALLER, and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, 
  J., concurring in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the majority that the post-conviction 
  relief judge erred in granting respondent a new trial.Â  It is apparent from 
  the trial record that counselâ€™s strategy was to exploit in closing argument 
  the only weakness in the Stateâ€™s case, that is, the inconsistencies between 
  the victimsâ€™ written statements and their trial testimony.Â  Having concluded 
  that counselâ€™s performance was not objectively unreasonable, I find it unnecessary 
  to reach the second prong of an ineffective assistance of counsel claim, that 
  is, whether respondent was prejudiced as a result of counselâ€™s actions.Â  

 
   
    [1]  Before trial, defense counsel negotiated a plea, which allowed Respondent 
    to plead to two counts of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  
    Respondent decided not to plead guilty to this lesser charge, and the trial 
    proceeded as a criminal sexual conduct case.

 
   
    [2]  Given the sensitive nature of this matter, we have chosen not to 
    disclose Motherâ€™s name and to use pseudonyms for the minorsâ€™ names. 

 
   
    [3]  Lisa was 13-years old at the time of trial and was either 12 or 13-years 
    old at the time the alleged incident occurred.Â  Â 

 
   
    [4]  The police did not take a statement from Lisa, Janeâ€™s friend who 
    was present during the game, but who apparently stopped participating after 
    she kissed Respondent.

 
   
    [5]  Again, John was 10-years old at the time, and in both his testimony 
    and his written statements, he did not allege that Respondent touched him.Â  
    And although defense counsel did not cross-examine Jill, he did attack her 
    credibility by having the State explain, on the record, that Jill had accused 
    someone else of criminal sexual conduct in the past and that the case had 
    been dismissed.

 
   
    [6]  By order dated August 13, 1999, this Court placed defense counsel 
    on incapacity inactive status.Â  In re Banks, 336 S.C. 334, 520 S.E.2d 
    316 (1999).Â  A year and a half later, this Court disbarred counsel for engaging 
    in check kiting, improperly converting funds, and violating record keeping 
    requirements.Â  In re Banks, 344 S.C. 17, 19-20, 542 S.E.2d 721, 722 
    (2001).Â  

 
   [7]  We 
    note that defense counsel did not appear at the PCR hearing, was subsequently 
    unreachable for deposition, and thus has never testified as to the trial strategy 
    employed in Respondentâ€™s case.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        David Mark Hill, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Aiken County
  Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25868
  Heard January 22, 2004 - Filed September 13, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART; VACATED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek and Jeffrey P. Bloom, 
          both of Columbia, for appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
          and Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia, and 
          Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Appellant was convicted 
  of capital murder and related charges for killing three employees at the Aiken 
  County Department of Social Services (DSS) on September 16, 1996.Â  We affirm 
  appellantâ€™s murder convictions and three death sentences, vacate his conviction 
  for attempted murder, and reverse his conviction for burglary.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND 
When these murders took place, appellant was married and had three children: 
  a three-year-old daughter who was a quadriplegic [1]  and twin two-year-old boys.Â  
  DSS became involved with the family because of concern about the parentsâ€™ abuse 
  of prescription drugs.Â  The children were eventually removed from the home.Â  

On the morning of September 16, 1996, appellant had a telephone conversation 
  with his caseworker, James Riddle.Â  Appellant then called his sister-in-law, 
  Tammy Campbell, to ask for a ride to the DSS office.Â  Tammy and her husband 
  gave appellant a ride to the Business & Technology Center where the DSS 
  office was located.Â  On the way, appellant said that he was tired of people 
  â€œplaying Godâ€ with his children.Â  The Campbells dropped appellant off at the 
  front of the building.
Sometime before 2:00 p.m., several DSS workers returned to work after a birthday 
  luncheon.Â  Annette Michael was walking towards her cubicle in the DSS office 
  area when another worker, Josie Currie, approached with her hands up.Â  Appellant 
  was behind Josie with a gun.Â  Josie asked Annette where James Riddleâ€™s office 
  was.Â  When Annette motioned with her hand, appellant told her to step in behind 
  Josie.Â  The three of them walked down the aisle to Jamesâ€™s cubicle.Â  James was 
  seated at his desk speaking on the telephone.Â  Josie stepped into the cubicle 
  and said, â€œThis man would like to see you.â€Â  
Appellant fired a shot into the cubicle, hitting James in the head.Â  He then 
  pointed the gun over Annetteâ€™s shoulder and shot Josie in the head.Â  Annette 
  fell with Josie as a third shot was fired.Â  Annette saw James fall over in his 
  chair and she saw a hole in his forehead before she fainted on the floor.Â  Another 
  DSS worker, Michael Gregory, was found dead of a gunshot wound in the menâ€™s 
  restroom. Both Josie and James died within the next few hours. Annette was not 
  injured.Â  
The next morning, police were still searching for appellant.Â  At around 9:20 
  a.m., appellant was found lying on the railroad tracks behind the building with 
  his gun nearby.Â  He had a bullet hole through the roof of his mouth and an exit 
  wound in the top of his skull.Â  Although he was seriously injured, appellant 
  was able to speak.Â  After he was taken to the hospital, he was given Miranda 
  warnings.Â  Appellant admitted to the shootings.Â  He said he first shot Michael 
  Gregory in the restroom because Gregory had seen him.Â  He shot James Riddle 
  because Riddle was his caseworker.Â  He shot Josie Currie â€œbecause she was black.â€Â  

At trial, defense counsel conceded appellant was guilty of the shootings 
  and urged that the real issue was the penalty to be imposed.Â  Appellant was 
  convicted of three counts of murder, one count of attempted murder, kidnapping, 
  second-degree burglary, and weapon charges.Â  At the penalty phase, the jury 
  found four aggravating circumstances: (1) murder while in commission of a burglary, 
  (2) kidnapping, (3) two or more persons murdered, and (4) risk of death of two 
  or more persons in a public place.Â  The jury returned three death sentences.
As to the guilt phase of the trial, appellant raises the following issues for 
  review:Â  

  
    1.
    
    Did the trial judge properly find appellant competent 
      to stand trial?
    
  
  
    2. 
    
    Did the trial court have subject matter jurisdiction 
      on the attempted murder charge?
    
  
  
    3.
    
    Did the trial judge properly deny a motion for 
      directed verdict on the burglary charge?
    
  
  
    4.
    
    Did the trial judge properly admit appellantâ€™s 
      statement regarding Josie Currie?
    
  

As to the penalty phase, appellant raises the following issues for review:

  
    5.
    
    Did the trial judge properly charge section 16-3-20(A) 
      as requested?
    
  
  
    6.
    
    Did the trial judge properly restrict voir 
      dire?
    
  

Law/Analysis
1.Â  Competence
Appellant contends the 
  trial judge erred in finding him competent to stand trial because of his memory 
  loss surrounding the murders.Â  We disagree.
The test for determining competency to stand trial is whether the defendant 
  has sufficient present ability to consult with his lawyer with a reasonable 
  degree of rational understanding and whether he has a rational as well as a 
  factual understanding of the proceedings against him.Â  State v. Weik, 
  356 S.C. 76, 81, 587 S.E.2d 683, 685 (2002), cert. denied, 539 U.S. 930 
  (2003); State v. Bell, 293 S.C. 391, 395-96, 360 S.E.2d 706, 708 (1987).Â  
  The defendant bears the burden of proving his incompetence by a preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Weik, 356 S.C. at 81, 587 S.E.2d at 685.Â  The trial 
  judgeâ€™s decision as to whether the defendant is competent to stand trial will 
  be upheld if supported by any evidence.Â  Id.
At the competency hearing, Dr. Evans testified appellant had frontal lobe damage 
  from the gunshot wound to his brain and some resulting memory loss after the 
  trauma.Â  Dr. Bellard testified appellant had difficulty with his memory during 
  the time leading up to the crime but admitted â€œit is possible [appellant] does 
  remember what happened during the crime.â€Â  Dr. Bellard further stated appellant 
  understood the charges against him and could follow the proceedings if he paid 
  attention.Â  The Stateâ€™s expert testified appellant was competent.Â  
The trial judge found appellant failed to prove by a preponderance of the evidence 
  that his alleged memory loss rendered him incompetent.Â  The evidence, which 
  indicates that appellant understood the charges and the proceedings, supports 
  this ruling.
2.Â  
  Attempted murder charge
Appellant was indicted 
  for assault with intent to kill (AWIK) and â€œattempted murderâ€ for shooting at 
  Annette Michael, whom he shot at but missed.Â  Because both charges involved 
  the same victim, the State elected to proceed on the attempted murder charge 
  rather than AWIK.Â  The indictment for AWIK was nol-prossed.Â  Appellant 
  was convicted of attempted murder and sentenced to life.Â  He contends the trial 
  court did not have subject matter jurisdiction of this charge under this Courtâ€™s 
  decision in State v. Sutton, 340 S.C. 393, 532 S.E.2d 283 (2000).Â  We 
  agree.
In State v. Sutton, the Court of Appeals held attempted murder is not 
  a recognized offense in South Carolina.Â  333 S.C. 192, 194, 508 S.E.2d 41, 42 
  (Ct. App. 1998).Â  This decision was filed October 26, 1998, and we granted certiorari 
  on July 8, 1999.Â  Appellantâ€™s trial commenced February 7, 2000.Â  On May 15, 
  2000, we affirmed as modified the Court of Appealsâ€™ ruling in Sutton, 
  holding that attempted murder is not a recognized offense in South Carolina.Â  
  340 S.C. at 398, 532 S.E.2d at 286. 
The State argues that in affirming the Court of 
  Appeals, we did not reiterate the Court of Appealsâ€™ analysis that such an offense 
  â€œnever existed,â€ but instead clarified the definition of AWIK and concluded 
  the offense of attempted murder is unnecessary.Â  The State claims our decision 
  is therefore a new rule that should apply prospectively only.Â  We disagree.Â  
  A decision announcing a new rule of law will be given retroactive effect to 
  all cases pending on direct review.Â  State v. Jones, 312 S.C. 100, 102, 
  439 S.E.2d 282, 282 (1994).Â  Accordingly, we vacate the attempted murder conviction 
  and the five-year sentence for possession of a firearm during the attempted 
  murder.
3.Â  Burglary conviction
Appellant was convicted of second-degree burglary under S.C. Code Ann. section 
  16-11-312(B)(1) (2003), which provides: 
 
  (B) A person is guilty of burglary in the second degree if the person enters 
    a building without consent and with intent to commit a crime therein, and 
    either:
   
     (1)   Â When, in effecting entry or while in the building or 
      in immediate flight therefrom, he or another participant in the crime:
     (a)Â  Is armed with a deadly weapon or explosive;Â  or
    (b)Â  Causes physical injury to any person who is not a participant in the 
      crime; or
    (c) Uses or threatens the use of a dangerous instrument; or
    (d) Displays what is or appears to be a knife, pistol, revolver, rifle, 
      shotgun, machine gun, or other firearm.Â Â  
  

Under section 16-11-310(1)(b), â€œbuildingâ€ includes 
  a structure where people assemble for purposes of business or government.Â  Further, 
  the same section states:Â  

  Where a building consists of two or more units separately occupied or 
    secured, each unit is deemed both a separate building in itself and a 
    part of the main building.

(emphasis added).
Appellant contends the trial judge erred in denying appellantâ€™s motion for directed 
  verdict on the burglary charge because there is no evidence he entered without 
  consent.Â  The State contends the DSS office area was â€œseparately securedâ€ from 
  the public area and, because appellant had no authority to enter that area, 
  his entry was without consent.
The DSS offices are located in the Business & Technology Center, also referred 
  to as the â€œBTC building.â€Â  Glass front doors are at the main entrance to the 
  building and these open onto the main hall that runs down the length of the 
  building with an exit at the end.Â  DSS has its own outside entrance on the right 
  side of the building that leads into the DSS lobby.Â  There is also a locked 
  employee entrance that opens directly into the office area of DSS.Â  From the 
  main building hallway, there are two inside entrances to the DSS area, one to 
  the DSS lobby and one to the DSS office area, which apparently was a locked 
  door with a buzzer.
Within the DSS area, there is a door between the lobby and the office area.Â  
  Typically, clients enter the DSS lobby, and the receptionist calls the DSS worker 
  who comes to the lobby and escorts the client back to the workerâ€™s office cubicle.Â  
  Clients generally are told they are not to go back into the office area unescorted.Â  
  There is no evidence, however, that this door was locked or even closed on the 
  day of the shootings.Â  In addition, there is no sign posted telling clients 
  not to enter.
Britt Campbell, who gave appellant a ride to the DSS office on the day of the 
  shootings, testified he saw appellant go to the front glass doors of the BTC 
  building, open the door, and take a step inside before Campbell drove away.Â  
  After the shootings, Appellant himself told police that he â€œentered the side 
  door and exited the back door.â€ [2] Â  There is no eyewitness testimony 
  indicating how appellant got into the DSS office area.Â  The first time he was 
  seen, he was already in the office area.Â  
The Stateâ€™s theory to support appellantâ€™s burglary conviction rests on the 
  statutory definition of â€œbuilding,â€ which includes a unit in a building that 
  has two or more units where each unit is â€œseparately occupied or secured.â€ S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-310(1)(b).Â  At least one other court has applied this statutory 
  term to find an area within a building to be separately secured if the unit 
  requires a separate key for entry.Â  Hawaii v. Vowell, 837 P.2d 1308, 
  1311-1312 (Haw. 1992); see also State v. Vinyard, 78 P.3d 1196, 
  1198 (Kan. App. 2003) (holding separate businesses in a shopping mall are separate 
  buildings).Â  In light of our rule that a penal statute must be strictly construed 
  against the State, State v. Muldrow, 348 S.C. 264, 268, 559 S.E.2d 847, 
  849 (2002), we construe â€œseparately occupied or securedâ€ to require some objective 
  manifestation that the unit is secure. [3] Â  
In this case, the evidence indicates that at least 
  one entry into the DSS office area was not securedâ€”the entry from the DSS lobby 
  into the office area.Â  There was no sign refusing admittance, no evidence the 
  door was secured, and no evidence appellant was denied entry.Â  We find the DSS 
  office area does not qualify as a separate building for purposes of the burglary 
  statute and reverse the denial of a directed verdict on this charge.
4.Â  Admission of statement
Appellant contends his 
  statement that he killed the third victim, Josie Currie, â€œbecause she was black,â€ 
  should have been suppressed as an involuntary statement because police told 
  him he was dying and because of his mental condition due to his brain injury.Â  
  We disagree. 
When appellant was found on the railroad tracks, he had a bullet wound in the 
  top of his head.Â  The arresting officers did not tell him he was dying.Â  Agent 
  McAlhany testified he thought appellant was dying but did not tell him.Â  Agent 
  Otterbacher did not recall telling appellant he was dying but did ask him if 
  he believed in God and, if so, he needed to ask Godâ€™s forgiveness.Â  
Appellant was then taken to the hospital where he was interviewed, with the 
  doctorsâ€™ permission, after being given Miranda warnings.Â  Appellant was 
  coherent and indicated he understood his rights when he gave the contested statement.Â  

A defendantâ€™s mental condition in and of itself does not render a statement 
  involuntary in violation of due process.Â  Absent coercive police conduct causally 
  related to a confession, there is no basis for finding a confession constitutionally 
  involuntary.Â  Colorado v. Connelly, 479 U.S. 157, 164 (1986); State 
  v. Hughes, 336 S.C. 585, 594, 521 S.E.2d 500, 505 (1999); see also State 
  v. Doby, 273 S.C. 704, 709, 258 S.E.2d 896, 899 (1979) (under state law, 
  a confession is not inadmissible because of mental deficiency alone).Â  
Agent Ottenbacherâ€™s suggestion that appellant ask 
  Godâ€™s forgiveness does not, on its face, rise to the level of police coercion.Â  
  In addition, there is no testimony in the record that appellant felt coerced 
  by this statement.Â  Appellantâ€™s mental condition alone does not support a finding 
  of involuntariness absent evidence of police coercion.Â  Accordingly, we conclude 
  that the trial judge properly admitted the statement.Â  State v. Owens, 
  346 S.C. 637, 660, 552 S.E.2d 745, 757 (2001) (conclusion of the trial judge 
  on issues of fact as to the voluntariness of a confession will not be disturbed 
  unless so manifestly erroneous as to show an abuse of discretion).
5.Â  Section 16-3-20(A)
During the penalty phase of trial, the defense put up an extensive case, including 
  mental health experts who testified as to appellantâ€™s mental illnesses 
  [4]  and prison officials who testified as to his good behavior while incarcerated. 

Captain Angie Pinkney, a shift supervisor at Lee Correctional Institute, 
  described prison conditions for inmates according to their classification.Â  
  â€œSafekeepersâ€ are inmates in maximum security.Â  They are kept in lockdown for 
  twenty-three out of twenty-four hours and escorted everywhere.Â  This was appellantâ€™s 
  classification.Â  On cross-examination, Captain Pinkney was asked if â€œgeneral 
  lifersâ€ were treated differently from those in maximum security.Â  She answered 
  that the level of freedom changes and inmates â€œhave much more flexibility out 
  there in the yard, they can leave at their leisure, go to work, school, they 
  have a job. . . .â€Â  
When the case was submitted to the jury, the trial judge properly charged 
  that life imprisonment means life without the possibility of parole.Â  After 
  the jury began deliberations, it returned with a question:Â  

  [Captain Pinkney] stated something to the fact that with a life sentence 
    Mr. Hill can go to school, work, etc. Please reiterate the response to the 
    solicitorâ€™s question.Â  Whatâ€™s the difference between life in prison and super 
    max.

The trial judge 
  then had Captain Pinkneyâ€™s testimony replayed.Â  He refused defense counselâ€™s 
  request that an additional charge be given based on S.C. Code Ann. section 16-3-20(A) 
  (Supp. 2003), which in pertinent part provides:
 
  
    A person who is convicted of or pleads guilty to murder must be punished 
      by death, by imprisonment for life, or by a mandatory minimum term of imprisonment 
      for thirty years. . . .No person sentenced to life imprisonment pursuant 
      to this section is eligible for parole, community supervision, or any early 
      release program, nor is the person eligible to receive any work credits, 
      education credits, good conduct credits, or any other credits that would 
      reduce the mandatory life imprisonment required by this section.
  

(emphasis added).Â  
  The trial judge ruled that the italicized language expressed only the legislatureâ€™s 
  intent that the mandatory term not be reduced and does not prohibit a person 
  sentenced to life imprisonment from working or seeking an education.Â  
A plain reading of the statute supports the trial judgeâ€™s interpretation.Â  
  The statute speaks strictly in terms of prohibiting credit for certain 
  activities but does not prohibit those activities in the day-to-day life of 
  an inmate sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  We find no error in refusing the 
  additional charge.
6.Â  
  Jury voir dire
During voir dire, the trial judge refused defense counselâ€™s request 
  to ask jurors whether they would give up their vote in order to go with the 
  majority.Â  Appellant contends this was error under State v. Bennett, 
  328 S.C. 251, 493 S.E.2d 845 (1997).Â  We disagree.Â  
In general, the scope of voir dire and the manner in which it is 
  conducted are within the trial judgeâ€™s sound discretion.Â  State v. Wise, 
  359 S.C. 14, 23, 596 S.E.2d 475, 479 (2004) (citations omitted).Â  To constitute 
  reversible error, a limitation on questioning must render the trial â€œfundamentally 
  unfair.â€Â  Morgan v. Illinois, 504 U.S. 719, 730, 112 S. Ct. 2222, 2230 
  (1992); State v. Hill, 331 S.C. 94, 104, 501 S.E.2d 122, 127 (1998).Â  
  On review, a jurorâ€™s responses must be examined in light of the entire voir 
  dire, with the primary consideration being that the juror is unbiased, impartial, 
  and capable of following instructions on the law.Â  State v. Green, 301 
  S.C. 347, 354, 392 S.E.2d 157, 161, cert. denied, 498 U.S. 881, 111 S. 
  Ct. 229 (1990).Â  
In Bennett, we found a juror unqualified 
  who, when asked, stated he could not go against the majority if the eleven other 
  jurors voted for death.Â  We held that the jurorâ€™s statement indicated he would 
  not have been able to follow the law as explained to him and his earlier generalized 
  statement that he could follow the law did not cure this deficiency.Â  Bennett, 
  328 S.C. at 257, 439 S.E.2d at 848.
But Bennett does not determine whether it 
  is appropriate, much less mandatory, for defense counsel to ask the â€œgo with 
  the majorityâ€ question.Â  In fact, the appropriateness of the question was not 
  at issue in Bennett; instead, the ultimate inquiry in Bennett 
  was whether the juror was â€œunbiased, impartial, and able to carry out the law 
  as explained to him.â€ Id.Â  Considering the voir dire as a whole, 
  we determined that the juror was not impartial.Â  Id.
In the present case, however, a review of the entire 
  voir dire reveals that the defendant had an impartial jury.Â  Prior to 
  qualification, the judge asked all potential jurors to read summaries of three 
  potential juror types:Â  (1) one who would feel required to give the death penalty 
  in every case where murder had been proved; (2) one who would not give the death 
  penalty under any circumstance, including when the defendant had been found 
  guilty of murder; and (3) one who would not have his or her mind made up in 
  advance concerning punishmentâ€”this person would need to hear the facts and circumstances 
  in aggravation and mitigation, and would want to listen to and follow the law 
  as charged before making a decision.Â  Qualified jurors indicated that they were 
  like the third type of jurorâ€”the kind of juror who would listen to all the circumstances 
  and follow the judgeâ€™s instructions on the law.Â  They were repeatedly questioned 
  by the State and the defense as to whether they understood the nature of this 
  category of potential jurors.
Moreover, there is no indication that the limitation on questioning affected 
  the selection of an impartial jury.Â  Appellant does not point to a single juror 
  whose responses vacillated or whose responses suggested that the juror was incapable 
  of hearing all of the evidence before making a decision.Â  Further, unlike the 
  question asked in Bennett, the question asked in the present case does 
  not probe whether jurors would automatically vote for death regardless of their 
  view on the evidence and therefore reveals little, if anything, about juror 
  impartiality.Â  In sum, a review of the entire voir dire indicates that 
  the jurors were unbiased, impartial, and capable of following instructions on 
  the law.
In the final analysis, what is constitutionally 
  mandated is the selection of a fair and impartial jury.Â  No particular formula 
  of questions is mandated to achieve this goal.Â  In our justice system, the trial 
  judge has the discretion and the duty to monitor the voir dire so as 
  to ensure that the jury selected measures up to the constitutional standard.Â  
  The judgeâ€™s ruling in this case, disallowing defense counsel to question jurors 
  about their propensity to go with the majority, did not render the trial â€œfundamentally 
  unfair.â€Â  Therefore, we affirm the trial judgeâ€™s decision on this issue.
CONCLUSION
Appellantâ€™s murder convictions and three death sentences are affirmed, the 
  convictions for attempted murder and the related weapon charge are vacated, 
  and the conviction for second-degree burglary is reversed.Â  Appellantâ€™s remaining 
  issues are without merit:Â  See Issue 4:Â  State v. Taylor, 333 
  S.C. 159, 508 S.E.2d 870 (1998) (prejudice must be shown from erroneous admission 
  or exclusion of evidence); Issues 8 & 9:Â  State v. Foye, 335 S.C. 
  586, 518 S.E.2d 265 (1999) (jury is presumed to follow instructions); State 
  v. Prince, 279 S.C. 30, 301 S.E.2d 471 (1983) (mistrial should not be granted 
  except in cases of manifest necessity); Issue 10:Â  State v. Colf, 337 
  S.C. 622, 525 S.E.2d 246 (2000) (trial judgeâ€™s ruling on scope of cross-examination 
  will be reversed only if showing of prejudice);Â  Issue 11:Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 
  339 S.C. 369, 529 S.E.2d 528 (2000) (trial judge has broad discretion in determining 
  whether to admit demonstrative evidence including charts and diagrams which 
  are not direct evidence and have only secondary relevance); Issue 12:Â  State 
  v. Colf, 337 S.C. at 625, 525 S.E.2d at 247-48 (no reversible error from 
  cross-examination without showing of prejudice); Issue 13:Â  State v. Matthews, 
  296 S.C. 379, 373 S.E.2d 587 (1988);Â  State v. Ivey, 325 S.C. 137, 481 
  S.E.2d 125 (1997) (where trial judgeâ€™s instructions defining life imprisonment 
  were sufficient to ensure jurorsâ€™ proper understanding, the question was properly 
  disallowed); Issue 14: State v. Hill, 331 S.C. 94, 501 S.E.2d 122 (1998) 
  (where general question covers the subject of mitigating circumstances, more 
  specific questions need not be allowed); Issue 15:Â  State v. Council, 
  335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999); State v. Davis, 309 S.C. 326, 422 
  S.E.2d 133 (1992) (whether juror is qualified to serve on a death penalty case 
  is within sole discretion of trial judge and is not reviewable on appeal unless 
  wholly unsupported by the evidence); State v. Tucker, 334 S.C. 1, 512 
  S.E.2d 99 (1998) (trial judgeâ€™s disqualification of a prospective juror will 
  not be disturbed where there is a reasonable basis from which trial judge could 
  have concluded the juror would not have been able to faithfully discharge her 
  responsibilities as a juror). 
AFFIRMED IN PART; VACATED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
BURNETT and Acting Justice James E. Brogdon, Jr., concur. Â MOORE, J., dissenting 
  in a separate opinion in which WALLER, J., concurs.

JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Because I disagree with the majorityâ€™s holding that 
  juror voir dire was properly limited, I respectfully dissent.Â  
In my view, our decision in State v. Bennett, 328 S.C. 251, 493 S.E.2d 
  845 (1997), is controlling here.Â  In Bennett, we found unqualified a 
  juror who stated he could not go against the majority if the eleven other jurors 
  voted for death.Â  We concluded the jurorâ€™s earlier generalized statement that 
  he could â€œfollow the lawâ€ did not cure this deficiency.Â  Our holding in Bennett 
  compels the conclusion that a jurorâ€™s general statement that he or she could 
  follow the law does not satisfy the specific inquiry defense counsel requested 
  here.Â  Cf. State v. Hill, 331 S.C. 94, 501 S.E.2d 122 (1998) (fundamental 
  fairness not violated by limited voir dire where other questions covered request).
Further, as noted by the United States Supreme Court, â€œThe measure of a jury 
  is taken by reference to the impartiality of each individual juror. . . . each 
  of these jurors must stand equally impartial in his or her ability to follow 
  the law.â€Â  Morgan v. Illinois, 504 U.S. 719, 735 (1992).Â  A jurorâ€™s ability 
  to decide the case independently of the majority is particularly relevant under 
  our capital sentencing scheme because even one vote for life will defeat a death 
  sentence.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20 (Supp. 2003) (where jury fails 
  to return unanimous verdict, the judge must impose a life sentence). [5] Â  It is therefore crucial that the defendant 
  be able to inquire whether a juror has a propensity to follow the majority.
In light of our sentencing scheme, 
  I would hold that fundamental fairness requires that the defense be allowed 
  to probe a jurorâ€™s ability to vote independently of the majority.Â  Accordingly, 
  I would reverse and remand for a new sentencing proceeding. 
WALLER, J., concurs.


 
   [1]  The daughter was injured when appellantâ€™s wife 
    had a car accident less than a year earlier.Â  

 
   [2]  A maintenance worker saw appellant 
    exit the back door of the building at the end of the main hallway. 

 [3] We are aware that other courts 
  addressing the issue of burglary in a public building have held that consent 
  to enter a public building is limited to the purpose for which the building 
  is open and therefore any unlawful act is without consent as a matter of law.Â  
  See, e.g., People v. Blair, 288 N.E.2d 443, 445 (Ill. 1972); State 
  v. Adams, 581 P.2d 868, 869 (Nev. 1978).Â  This approach has been criticized, 
  however, because it elevates every crime committed in a public building, such 
  as shoplifting, to a burglary.Â  State v. Hall, 3 P.3d 582, 585 (Kan. 
  App. 2000), affâ€™d, 14 P.3d 404, 409 (Kan. 2000).Â 

 [4]  Appellant was diagnosed with post-traumatic stress 
    disorder, panic disorder, and major depression.

 
   [5] The 
    jury, however, need not be told the consequences of its failure to agree.Â  
    Jones v. United States, 527 U.S. 373 (1999).Â  Here the jury was charged 
    it must be unanimous in imposing a life or death sentence.Â
