description: The Court of Appeals dismissed Petitioner's appeal as untimely.  The Supreme Court reversed, holding that Petitioner's written post-trial motion filed pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, was timely and appropriate.  Therefore, Petitioner's appeal was timely filed within the thirty-day deadline after Petitioner received written notice of entry of the order denying its Rule 59(e) motion.  Petitioner's written Rule 59(e) motion, which followed a motion for a new trial Petitioner had made orally at the end of the trial, was not barred even though Petitioner raised the same arguments it had raised in the new trial motion.  Clarifying the application of three previous opinions of the appellate courts, the Supreme Court concluded that "a party usually is free to file an initial Rule 59(e) motion, regardless of whether the previous JNOV/new trial motions were made orally or in writing, without unnecessary concern the repetition of an issue or argument made in a previous motion will result in a subsequent appeal being dismissed as untimely."  The Supreme Court cautioned parties who file post-trial motions to note carefully the exceptions to this general rule as expressed in the previous cases.  The Supreme Court also overruled a recent conflicting Court of Appeals' opinion addressing the same issue.  Lastly, the Supreme Court addressed the merits of Petitioner's appeal and affirmed the jury's verdict in favor of Respondent.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        Hattie Rose Elam, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        South Carolina Department of Transportation, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Allendale County
  Â Daniel E. Martin, Sr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25869
  Heard November 19, 2003 - Filed September 13, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Pete Kulmala, of Harvey & Kulmala, of Barnwell, for Petitioner.
        H. Woodrow Gooding, Jr. and Mark B. Tinsley, of Gooding and Gooding, 
          of Allendale, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  We granted the petition for a writ of certiorari 
  to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ unpublished order dismissing the appeal of the 
  South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) as untimely.Â  Elam v. 
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., S.C. Ct. App. Order dated July 25, 2002.Â  
  We reverse.
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Respondent Hattie Rose Elam (Elam) sued Petitioner (SCDOT) under the South 
  Carolina Tort Claims Act [1]  
  for personal injuries and property damage sustained by Elam in a single-car 
  accident which occurred in March 1998.Â  Elam alleged the accident was caused 
  by SCDOTâ€™s improper maintenance of a highway, which allowed excessive rain water 
  to accumulate on the highway.
At the conclusion of Elamâ€™s case, SCDOT moved for a directed verdict on various 
  grounds.Â  The trial court denied the motion and submitted the case to the jury 
  on January 10, 2001.Â  The jury returned a verdict for Elam for $250,000.Â  Immediately 
  thereafter, SCDOT made oral motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict 
  (JNOV) and a new trial absolute, or in the alternative, for a new trial nisi 
  remittitur.Â  SCDOTâ€™s motions were denied by the trial judge in an oral ruling 
  from the bench, and a one-page Form 4 order was filed with the clerk on January 
  11, 2001, effecting entry of the juryâ€™s verdict.Â Â Â  
SCDOT timely filed a written motion pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  The trial 
  court denied the Rule 59(e) motion in a written order dated April 6, 2001.Â  
  SCDOT served its notice of appeal on April 27, 2001, and in its appeal contested 
  the trial courtâ€™s denial of its motions for JNOV and new trial.
The Court of Appeals, sua sponte, raised the issue of the timeliness 
  of SCDOTâ€™s appeal in light of Quality Trailer Products v. CSL Equipment Co., 
  349 S.C. 216, 562 S.E.2d 615 (2002), and directed the parties brief the issue.Â  
  The Court of Appeals subsequently concluded SCDOTâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion merely 
  repeated grounds previously raised to and ruled on by the trial judge as a result 
  of SCDOTâ€™s oral JNOV/new trial motions.Â  Therefore, the Rule 59(e) motion did 
  not stay the running of the thirty-day deadline to appeal and SCDOTâ€™s appeal 
  was dismissed as untimely.
ISSUES
 
  
    I.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in finding SCDOTâ€™s appeal untimely because 
      its written Rule 59(e) motion, which repeated grounds previously raised 
      to and ruled on by the trial judge as a result of oral JNOV/new trial motions 
      made immediately after the juryâ€™s verdict, did not stay the time to appeal?
    II.Â  Did the trial court err in denying SCDOTâ€™s motion to amend its answer 
      and its post-trial motions?
  

DISCUSSION
I.Â  Timeliness of SCDOTâ€™s appeal
We take this opportunity to clarify the limits and rationale of Quality 
  Trailer, supra, and two Court of Appealsâ€™ opinions, Coward Hund 
  Const. Co. v. Ball Corp., 336 S.C. 1, 518 S.E.2d 56 (Ct. App. 1999), and 
  Collins Music Co. v. IGT, 353 S.C. 559, 579 S.E.2d 524 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
  We conclude the Court of Appeals in the present case and in Matthews v. Richland 
  County School Dist. One, 357 S.C. 594, 594 S.E.2d 177 (Ct. App. 2004) has 
  extended the holdings and rationale of those three cases in a manner which unnecessarily 
  complicates post-trial and appellate practice.Â  
Post-trial motions such as a JNOV or new trial motion â€œshall be made promptly 
  after the jury is discharged, or in the discretion of the court not later than 
  10 days thereafter.â€Â  Rules 50(e) and 59(b), SCRCP.Â  In actions tried without 
  a jury or with an advisory jury, a party may move the court to amend its findings 
  or judgment or for a new trial not later than 10 days after receipt of written 
  notice of entry of judgment.Â  Rule 52(a), SCRCP.
The notice of appeal in a case appealed from the Court of Common Pleas must 
  be served on all respondents within thirty days after receipt of written notice 
  of entry of the order or judgment.Â  Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR.Â  The requirement 
  of service of the notice of appeal is jurisdictional, i.e., if a party 
  misses the deadline, the appellate court lacks jurisdiction to consider the 
  appeal and has no authority or discretion to â€œrescueâ€ the delinquent party by 
  extending or ignoring the deadline for service of the notice.Â  Mears v. Mears, 
  287 S.C. 168, 337 S.E.2d 206 (1985).Â  A timely post-trial motion, including 
  a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, stays 
  the time for an appeal for all parties until receipt of written notice of entry 
  of the order granting or denying such motion.Â  See Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR; 
  Rules 50(e), 52(c), and 59(f), SCRCP.
The Court of Appeals in 1999 took the first step toward Quality Trailer 
  in Coward Hund, 336 S.C. 1, 518 S.E.2d 56.Â  In that case, the trial court 
  by written order granted summary judgment to the defendants.Â  Appellant Coward 
  Hund timely served a written â€œmotion for reconsiderationâ€ pursuant to Rule 59(e), 
  SCRCP.Â  The trial court heard oral arguments on the Rule 59(e) motion and issued 
  a written order denying the motion.Â  Coward Hund subsequently filed a second, 
  written motion for reconsideration pursuant to Rule 59(e), seeking clarification 
  of the courtâ€™s ruling on an issue on which the court had ruled.Â  After a telephone 
  conference, the trial court issued a supplemental written order again denying 
  Coward Hundâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion.Â  Coward Hund served its notice of appeal within 
  thirty days of receipt of written notice of entry of the order denying its second

  with the South Carolina Highway Patrol, testified there had been numerous accidents 
  during the past eight years at the same location.Â  Sergeant King testified he 
  had reported the condition to SCDOT on numerous occasions. Given the testimony 
  of these witnesses and others, the jury could reasonably have found SCDOT negligent 
  in failing to properly maintain the highway.
SCDOT argues the trial court erred in denying its motions for a directed verdict 
  and JNOV based on the absence of notice of the defect after the departmentâ€™s 
  remedial work actions and prior to Elamâ€™s accident.Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling the evidence presented a jury question on whether SCDOT took any remedial 
  actions.Â  See Strange, supra.
CONCLUSION
We reaffirm the principles set forth in Coward Hund, 336 S.C. 1, 518 
  S.E.2d 56; Quality Trailer, 349 S.C. 216, 562 S.E.2d 615; and Collins 
  Music, 353 S.C. 559, 579 S.E.2d 524.Â  We reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ order 
  in the present case and overrule the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Matthews, 
  357 S.C. 594, 594 S.E.2d 177.Â  We conclude SCDOT timely served its notice of 
  appeal after receipt of written notice of entry of the order denying its Rule 
  59(e) motion.
On the merits of SCDOTâ€™s appeal, the trial court did not err in denying SCDOTâ€™s 
  motion to amend its answer or its motions for a directed verdict, JNOV, and 
  new trial.Â  Accordingly, we reinstate the juryâ€™s verdict in favor of Elam and 
  remand this case to circuit court for entry of judgment on the verdict.
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., and MOORE, J., concur.Â  WALLER, J., dissenting in a separate 
  opinion in which PLEICONES, J., concurs.

 
JUSTICE WALLER: Â I respectfully dissent.Â  
  In my opinion, SCDOTâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion, raising the same issues orally raised 
  to and ruled upon in its motions for directed verdict, JNOV, and a new trial, 
  did not stay the time for filing a notice of appeal.Â  I would affirm the Court 
  of Appealsâ€™ holding that SCDOTâ€™s appeal was untimely.Â  
Post-trial motions are required in two primary 
  circumstances:Â  to preserve issues that have been raised to the trial court 
  but not yet ruled upon or when the trial court grants relief not requested or 
  rules on an issue never raised at trial.Â  Jean Hoefer Toal, et al, Appellate 
  Practice in South Carolina 59-60 (2d ed. 2002).Â  Issues are preserved for 
  appeal even where a JNOV motion is denied in a form order, if the issues have 
  been adequately raised and argued to the court and the record on appeal contains 
  transcripts of the court proceedings.Â  Bailey v. Segars, 346 S.C. 359, 
  550 S.E.2d 910 (Ct. App. 2001).
Here, SCDOT repeatedly argued its position to the 
  trial court: in its directed verdict motion, in renewing its directed verdict 
  motion, in its motion for JNOV, and in its motion for a new trial.Â  Each time 
  the trial judge denied SCDOTâ€™s motions.Â  Two years ago, in Quality Trailer 
  Products v. CSL Equipment Co. Inc., 349 S.C. 216, 565 S.E.2d 615 (2002), 
  we held the filing of a successive motion, raising issues already raised to 
  and ruled upon by the trial judge, does not stay the time to appeal.Â Â  Nothing 
  in Quality Trailer limited our holding to the filing of written 
  post-trial motions.Â  In my opinion, once a litigant has fully argued, either 
  orally or in writing, its post-trial motions to a judge, and obtained a ruling 
  thereon, there is simply no need to permit the same exact arguments to be re-raised 
  in a subsequent Rule 59(e) motion.Â Â  
I would hold SCDOT had its one full bite at the 
  apple such that the filing of its written Rule 59(e) motion did not stay the 
  time for filing an appeal in this case.Â  I would affirm the Court of Appealsâ€™ 
  opinion.  [6] 
PLEICONES, J., concurs.


 
   [1]  
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-10 to -200 (Supp. 2003).

 
   [2] Â  We are aware that a party may 
    attempt to file both a Rule 59 motion and a notice of appeal.Â  If this does 
    occur, one or the other will be inappropriate depending on whether the motion 
    is both timely under Rule 59 and permissible under our ruling today.Â  Cf. 
    Hudson v. Hudson, 290 S.C. 215, 349 S.E.2d 341 (1986) (holding that 
    when a timely post-trial motion is pending before the lower court, any notice 
    of appeal will be dismissed without prejudice as premature).Â  It is, of course, 
    the partyâ€™s responsibility to determine whether a Rule 59 motion or notice 
    of appeal is appropriate under the facts of the case, and we caution parties 
    not to attempt to avoid this responsibility by the simple expedient of filing 
    both.

 
   [3] Â  Rule 59(e), SCRCP, provides:
    Motion to Alter or Amend a Judgment.Â  A motion to alter or amend the judgment 
    shall be served not later than 10 days after receipt of written notice of 
    the entry of the order.
  Rule 59(e), FRCP, provides:
    Motion to Alter or Amend Judgment.Â  Any motion to alter or amend a judgment 
    shall be filed no later than 10 days after entry of the judgment.
  
 
   [4] Â  In discussing the need for a 
    Rule 59(e) motion, we explained that


  [t]he losing party must first try to convince the lower court it 
    has ruled wrongly and then, if that effort fails, convince the appellate court 
    that the lower court erred. This principle underlies the long-established 
    preservation requirement that the losing party generally must both present 
    his issues and arguments to the lower court and obtain a ruling before an 
    appellate court will review those issues and arguments. . . .
  If the losing party has raised an issue in the lower court, but 
    the court fails to rule upon it, the party must file a motion to alter or 
    amend the judgment in order to preserve the issue for appellate review. . 
    . . Imposing this preservation requirement on the appellant is meant to enable 
    the lower court to rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, 
    law, and arguments.Â  The requirement also serves as a keen incentive for a 
    party to prepare a case thoroughly.Â  It prevents a party from keeping an ace 
    card up his sleeve - intentionally or by chance - in the hope that an appellate 
    court will accept that ace card and, via a reversal, give him another opportunity 
    to prove his case.


  Iâ€™On, 338 S.C. at 422, 526 S.E.2d at 724.

 
   [5] Â  We are presented in 
    this case with a party which believed a Rule 59(e) motion was necessary and 
    appropriate.Â  We do not mean to imply by our emphasis on the potential importance 
    of such a motion that one is necessary or desirable in every case.Â  An aggrieved 
    party who is confident his issues and arguments were sufficiently raised to 
    and ruled on by the trial court may wish to simply file and serve a timely 
    notice of appeal.Â Â Â Â  

 
   [6] Â  I would also affirm the opinion in Matthews 
    v. Richland County School Dist. One, 357 S.C. 594, 594 S.E.2d 177 (Ct. 
    App. 2004).Â

title: Roberts v. State
description: Issue is whether counsel was ineffective for failing to present evidence regarding the distance between respondentâ€™s and another imate's jail cells
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        Jason Roberts, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRITE OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Laurens County
  Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25870
  Submitted May 13, 2004 - Filed September 13, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
          and Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, all 
          of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  Respondent was convicted of murder and sentenced to 
  life imprisonment.Â  Respondent filed an application for post-conviction relief 
  (PCR), which was granted on a number of grounds.Â  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s 
  petition for a writ of certiorari.Â  We hold there is probative evidence to support 
  the PCR judgeâ€™s decision.Â  
FACTS
On January 10, 1992, Bobby Marler was found robbed 
  and beaten to death in his pawnshop in Laurens.Â  In early 1993, Thomas E. Whitehead, 
  Jr. gave police a statement about the murder, implicating respondent.Â  From 
  February 1993 to February 1994, Whitehead gave four vastly different statements 
  to police, and was eventually promised by the Sheriffâ€™s Department that he would 
  not be charged with murder in return for his testimony. [1] 
Â In Whiteheadâ€™s first statement, which he made on February 26, 1993, Whitehead 
  told police that Jaime McAlister and respondent committed the crime.Â  Whitehead 
  told police that he was not involved.Â  Whitehead claimed respondent told him 
  he and McAlister originally went to Marlerâ€™s pawnshop to buy marijuana, but 
  that the two ended up robbing and killing Marler.Â  However, McAlister was in 
  jail on the night of the murder, and could not have been involved.Â  Further, 
  Whitehead admitted at trial that police suggested to him that McAlister was 
  involved.
In the second statement, made on November 22, 1993, 
  Whitehead again claimed McAlister and respondent committed the crime.Â  Whitehead 
  told police respondent and McAlister used a baseball bat to beat Marler, and 
  that he saw a silver baseball bat in the hatchback of Matt Cagleâ€™s 
  [2]  car.Â  Whitehead also claimed respondent used the money from the robbery 
  to buy cocaine. Whitehead admitted at trial that the statement was false.Â Â Â  

Whitehead made a third statement on February 8, 
  1994.Â  In that statement, Whitehead again implicated respondent and McAlister.Â  
  It appears that shortly after the third statement, police finally discovered 
  McAlister was incarcerated the night of the murder and could not have been involved.Â Â Â Â Â  

The sheriffâ€™s office promised Whitehead that he 
  would not be charged with murder before Whitehead provided the fourth statement 
  in late February 1994. [3] Â  In 
  the fourth statement, Whitehead admitted he was involved, and told police substantially 
  the same story that he told at trial.Â  Â 
Whitehead testified at trial that he, respondent, and Matt Cagle drank beer 
  and liquor at respondentâ€™s house and in Cagleâ€™s car on the day of the murder.Â  
  When they needed money to buy more alcohol, the three decided to pawn respondentâ€™s 
  .22 rifle.Â  Whitehead testified that while Cagle stayed in the car, he and respondent 
  went into Marlerâ€™s pawnshop.Â  When Marler opened his wallet to pay for the rifle, 
  he and respondent noticed that Marler had a substantial amount of money.Â  Whitehead 
  testified that respondent pushed Marler to the floor and beat him in the head 
  and chest with the rifle butt.Â  The two grabbed Marlerâ€™s wallet and fled.Â  The 
  next day, after spending the night at respondentâ€™s house, Whitehead, Cagle, 
  and respondent went to Cagleâ€™s house and put the gun in Cagleâ€™s fatherâ€™s furnace 
  to melt it down. [4] 
During the presentation of respondentâ€™s case, respondentâ€™s mother testified 
  that he was in night school at the time of the murder, and that she picked him 
  up after school that evening.Â  However, the school did not have any attendance 
  records because respondent was auditing his classes.Â  Respondentâ€™s mother also 
  testified that Whitehead and Cagle did not spend the night at her house as Whitehead 
  had claimed in his testimony.Â  
Cagle testified he was not involved in the murder. Â Cagle testified he went 
  to a birthday party in Greenville on the night of January 9, 1992, and spent 
  the night there because he was too drunk to drive home.Â  Several other witnesses 
  corroborated Cagleâ€™s testimony, including Christopher Thornhill, who testified 
  he remembered the date because it was his birthday.Â  
Angela McAlister testified at trial that sometime after the murder, Whitehead 
  visited her son, [5]  who was 
  ill.Â  She testified that she stood in the hall and overheard Whitehead tell 
  her son that he should have killed a man named Bob Holmes and that he â€œ[c]ouldâ€™ve 
  gotten away with it because him and his daddy did because of the old fart they 
  murdered . . . out in front of the Wal-Mart.â€ [6] Â  
Respondent also presented the testimony of William Anthony Patterson, who stated 
  that he operated the furnace Whitehead claimed was used to melt the gun.Â  Patterson 
  testified that the furnace was not installed until March 1992.Â  Cagleâ€™s father 
  corroborated Pattersonâ€™s testimony, and also added that the furnace did not 
  have a propane tank attached until April 1992.Â  An employee with PNG Propane 
  testified that he installed a propane tank for an aluminum smelter for Cagleâ€™s 
  father on March 17, 1992, and that there were no other gas lines in place on 
  that date.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The State also presented testimony from Gary Gleen.Â  Gleen testified at trial 
  that respondent confessed to him while the two were incarcerated at the Broad 
  River Correctional Facility.Â  Gleen described himself as a â€œparalegal,â€ and 
  testified that he and respondent first discussed the charges in the Monticello 
  Dormitory in Broad River.Â  Gleen testified that respondent initially denied 
  he was involved in the murder.Â  
However, Gleen testified that after the two were 
  transferred to the Saluda Dormitory, respondent discussed the case with him 
  again and admitted he murdered Marler.Â  Gleen testified that he was in cell 
  106, and that respondent was in another cell, which was ten feet away, 
  when the conversations took place.Â  Gleen testified that respondent told him, 
  â€œYeah, well, I killed a man but they ainâ€™t got nothing on me.â€Â  Gleen admitted 
  others could overhear the conversations, but claimed he and respondent â€œwould 
  pull ourselves closer so that the voice would only carry towards each other,â€ 
  and that he and respondent simply stopped talking when guards or inmates would 
  pass.Â  
Using notes, Gleen testified that respondent knew 
  Whitehead had given police a statement, but that respondent thought he could 
  â€œbeat the crimeâ€ because witnesses would testify he was at school when the murder 
  occurred.Â  Gleen testified that respondent told him he did not have any intention 
  of killing Marler, but that Marler â€œgot smart and acted like he wouldnâ€™t take 
  the gun.â€Â  Gleen testified that respondent showed him how he beat Marler and 
  told him how he melted down the gun after the murder.Â  Gleen further testified 
  that respondent had a â€œgleam in his eyeâ€ when he talked about he murder.Â  
ISSUE

  Did the PCR judge err in finding that counsel was ineffective for failing 
    to present evidence regarding the distance between Gleen and respondentâ€™s 
    cells?

The State contends the PCR judge erred in finding that counsel was ineffective 
  for failing to present evidence that respondentâ€™s conversations with Gleen were 
  impossible.Â  We disagree.
The burden is on the applicant in a post-conviction 
  proceeding to prove the allegations in his application.Â  Butler v. State, 
  286 S.C. 441, 442, 334 S.E.2d 813, 814 (1985).Â  In order to establish a claim 
  of ineffective assistance of trial counsel, a PCR applicant must prove that: 
  (1) counselâ€™s performance was deficient, and (2) the deficient performance prejudiced 
  the applicantâ€™s case.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984); 
  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 117, 386 S.E.2d 624, 625 (1989).Â  To show 
  that counsel was deficient, the applicant must establish that counsel failed 
  to render reasonably effective assistance under prevailing professional norms.Â  
  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 688.Â  To show prejudice, the applicant must show 
  that, but for counselâ€™s errors, there is a reasonable probability the result 
  of the trial would have been different.Â  Johnson v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 
  186, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997).Â  A reasonable probability is a probability 
  sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome of trial.Â  Id. at 186, 
  480 S.E.2d at 735.
This Court gives great deference to the PCR judgeâ€™s 
  findings when matters of credibility are involved.Â  Drayton v. Evatt, 
  312 S.C. 4, 13, 430 S.E.2d 517, 522 (1993).Â  The existence in the record of 
  any evidence of probative value is sufficient to uphold the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  
  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109-10, 525 S.E.2d 514, 517 (2000).Â  

At the PCR hearing, respondent testified that he and Gleen were both inmates 
  in Saluda Dormitory at the Broad River Correctional Facility. Respondent admitted 
  that he talked to Gleen about the case.Â  However, respondent maintained that 
  he told Gleen he did not commit the crime.Â  Respondent testified that it was 
  impossible for the conversation to have taken place as Gleen maintained, and 
  that the distance between the cells was approximately thirty-five feet, not 
  ten feet.Â  Respondent further testified that there were seventy inmates in Saluda 
  Dormitory when he was incarcerated there.Â  Respondent then presented a videotape 
  of the prison dormitory to show the noise level in the dormitory and the distance 
  between the cells. [7] Â Â  
Ricky Higgs testified at the PCR hearing that he 
  and respondent were next door to each other in segregated lockup in Saluda Dormitory.Â  
  Higgs stated that respondentâ€™s cell was approximately thirty-five feet from 
  Gleenâ€™s cell, and that the noise in Saluda was â€œdeafeningâ€ at times.Â  Higgs 
  testified that, while it was possible to have a conversation with someone in 
  the next cell because of shared ventilation systems, one would have to yell 
  to be heard by someone in another cell.Â  Higgs testified that he heard respondent 
  and Gleen yelling across the breezeway about respondentâ€™s case.Â  However, Higgs 
  stated that respondent never confessed to Gleen. 
Trial counsel testified that Gleen was not listed 
  as a witness in the initial discovery response and that he was not aware Gleen 
  would testify until a short time before the trial.Â  Trial counsel remembered 
  discussing with respondent that it was physically impossible to have the discussion 
  Gleen described because of the layout of Saluda Dormitory.Â  However, counsel 
  did not cross-examine Gleen about the configuration of the cells, and he failed 
  to present any evidence about the setup of Saluda Dormitory.Â  
The PCR judge found that the videotape showed respondentâ€™s 
  cell was one hundred feet away from Gleenâ€™s, and it was therefore impossible 
  for the conversation to have taken place as Gleen alleged.Â  The PCR judge found 
  that if this evidence had been presented at trial, it would have had a significant 
  impact on the credibility of Gleen, who was a key witness for the State.Â  The 
  PCR judge also ruled that the evidence would have been available at trial if 
  trial counsel had made diligent efforts to obtain it.Â  Finally, the PCR judge 
  found there was a reasonable probability the result at trial would have been 
  different had trial counsel presented the evidence to the jury.Â  
Even conceding that respondent engaged in some conversations with Gleen, it 
  is highly unlikely that respondent confessed to murder across a cellblock from 
  a distance of thirty-five to one hundred feet.Â  There was evidence at the PCR 
  hearing that numerous other inmates and guards would have overheard respondent, 
  as it would have been necessary to shout over the television and other noise.Â  
  Additionally, counsel admitted that he was somewhat unprepared for Gleenâ€™s testimony, 
  and counsel failed to refute Gleenâ€™s assertion that the cells were no more than 
  ten feet apart at trial.Â  See Davis v. State, 326 S.C. 283, 288, 
  486 S.E.2d 747, 749 (1997) (evidence supported PCR judgeâ€™s ruling that counsel 
  was deficient, in part because counsel admitted he was unprepared for trial).
While we acknowledge that this is a close case, there is at least some probative 
  evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  We agree with the PCR judgeâ€™s finding 
  that, had counsel presented evidence that the jail cells were more than a mere 
  ten feet apart, there is a reasonable probability the result at trial would 
  have been different.Â  This evidence was particularly important in light of the 
  fact that the case against respondent was far from overwhelming, and consisted 
  almost entirely of the testimony of Whitehead, a codefendant who implicated 
  an innocent man in three false statements, and Gleen, a jailhouse snitch.Â  Additionally, 
  we note that there was evidence presented at trial and at PCR that Whitehead 
  told several people that he and his father committed the crime and that respondent 
  was not involved.Â  Further, the jury returned during deliberations and actually 
  asked the trial judge â€œwho was on trialâ€ in the case. 
  [8] Â  The trial judge simply told the jury that respondent was on trial. [9]  
Accordingly, we hold there is probative evidence 
  to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that counsel was deficient for failing to 
  present evidence of the cell configuration.Â  See Caprood, id. 
  at 109-10, 525 S.E.2d at 517; Webb v. State, 281 S.C. 237, 238, 314 S.E.2d 
  839, 839 (1984). Â 
CONCLUSION
We affirm the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling that counsel was 
  ineffective for failing to present evidence regarding the configuration of the 
  cells.Â  Accordingly, we need not address the Stateâ€™s remaining questions.Â  See 
  Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 
  S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding that an appellate court need not address all 
  remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive).
AFFIRMED.Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


 
   [1]  None of these statements 
    are included in the record, though it appears some were written and others 
    were recorded, and some were admitted as evidence.

 
   
    [2]  Cagle was another friend of both Whitehead and respondent.Â  Cagle 
    was later charged in connection with the murder.Â  

 
   [3]  Whitehead testified against 
    respondent in exchange for a five-year sentence.Â  He served three.

 
   [4]  The furnace was used 
    to melt aluminum, though it would not melt steel.Â  There was testimony that 
    the wood component of the rifle burned, but the barrel and other steel components 
    of the rifle would not melt.Â  It is unclear what happened to the steel components 
    of the rifle, though there was testimony they were simply â€œraked outâ€ and 
    left on the ground.Â Â Â  

 
   
    [5]  Angela McAlister is the mother of Jaime McAlister.Â  

 
   
    [6]  Marlerâ€™s pawnshop was located across from the Wal-Mart Distribution 
    Center in Laurens.Â  

 
   [7]  Unfortunately, the videotape 
    is defective and the Court has been unable to view it. 

 
   [8]  The jury actually asked two questions, neither 
    of which is included in the record.Â  The parties have been unable to locate 
    the exhibits. 

 
   
    [9]  We also note that the PCR judge found trial counsel was ineffective 
    for failing to move for a mistrial when the jury returned with this question. 
    The State seeks reversal on this issue; however, because we hold that the 
    PCR judge correctly granted relief on the question of Gleenâ€™s testimony, we 
    need not address whether the PCR judge erred in ruling counsel was ineffective 
    for failing to move for a mistrial following the jury question.Â Â Â Â

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        In the Matter of Former Beaufort Municipal Court Judge George H. Oâ€™Kelley, 
          Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  



Opinion No. 25871
  Submitted August 3, 2004 - Filed September 13, 2004

PUBLIC REPRIMAND

 
   
     
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Assistant Deputy 
          Attorney General Robert E. Bogan, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary 
          Counsel. 
        George H. Oâ€™Kelley, Jr., of Beaufort, pro se.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the 
  Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline 
  by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent 
  admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of either an admonition or 
  a public reprimand pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  We accept 
  the agreement and impose a public reprimand, the most severe sanction we are 
  able to impose under the circumstances.Â  The facts as set forth in the agreement 
  are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Respondent was an associate municipal judge for the City of Beaufort from approximately 
  1996 until his resignation in October 2003.Â  Among other things, his duties 
  as associate judge required him to adjudicate parking tickets.Â  
In Beaufort, the recipient of a parking ticket may either pay the fine or appear 
  in court to contest the ticket.Â  If the violator chooses to pay the fine, he 
  or she may remit payment by mail, take it to City Hall, or place the ticket 
  and payment in courtesy boxes located on certain parking meters.Â  Police Officer 
  John Oâ€™Neill, who is assigned parking enforcement duties in the downtown district, 
  collects the tickets and payments from the courtesy boxes and delivers them 
  to City Hall.Â  
ODC is informed that violators who appear in court to contest a parking ticket 
  are heard last and, unless they are repeat offenders, usually have the charge 
  dismissed (i.e., reduced to a warning).Â  This disposition is indicated by the 
  presiding judge writing â€œwarningâ€ across the ticket along with his or her signature.
Police officers have no further contact with a parking ticket after it is issued.Â  
  Police officers do not appear in court against violators who wish to contest 
  parking tickets and do not know whether tickets are contested, paid, or dismissed, 
  except that Officer Oâ€™Neill has some knowledge which tickets are paid when he 
  retrieves tickets from the courtesy boxes. 
In October 2003, while retrieving tickets from the courtesy boxes, Officer 
  Oâ€™Neill noticed particular tickets signed by respondent had been marked â€œwarningâ€ 
  and placed in a courtesy box.Â  Officer Oâ€™Neill recognized the tickets as those 
  he had issued two days in a row to a Volvo bearing South Carolina license 120KMP 
  and which he knew was usually driven by respondentâ€™s wife.Â  Officer Oâ€™Neill 
  brought this to the attention of the City Manager, who brought it to the attention 
  of the Chief Municipal Judge and City Attorney.Â  An inquiry was made as to other 
  parking tickets issued to this tag number.Â  It was determined that fourteen 
  additional tickets had been issued to the above-referenced vehicle.Â  Thirteen 
  of those fourteen tickets also had been dismissed by respondent.Â  The fourteenth 
  ticket had been unpaid for over three years.Â  
An emergency session of the Beaufort City Council was convened to consider 
  this matter.Â  Respondent acknowledged having dismissed the above-referenced 
  tickets.Â  By a 3-2 vote, the City Council asked respondent to submit his resignation.Â  
  Respondent resigned.
Respondent self-reported this matter to ODC.Â  ODC made an examination of 1) 
  parking tickets issued to other vehicles owned by respondent and 2) all parking 
  tickets dismissed by respondent during the period of January 2001 until his 
  resignation in October 2003.Â  The investigation revealed: 

   
    1.
    
    Five tickets were issued to respondentâ€™s other 
      vehicles.Â  Four of these tickets were dismissed by respondent and one was 
      marked â€œvoidâ€ by the issuing officer.Â  The voided ticket had been issued 
      when respondent blocked-in a vehicle which had parked unlawfully in the 
      space respondent reserves from the City.Â  Two of the dismissed tickets were 
      tickets issued to respondent while he was parked in his reserved space, 
      but in a vehicle which did not have the reserved parking placard affixed 
      to the rear view mirror.Â  The remaining two tickets dismissed by respondent 
      were for meter violations in the vicinity of his law office.
    
  
   
    2.
    During the period from January 2001 through October 
      2003,Â fifty-five additional parking tickets were marked â€œwarningâ€ byÂ Â  respondent.Â  
      Because tickets dismissed in court are marked in the same manner, it is 
      impossible to distinguish which of these tickets were marked â€œwarningâ€ prior 
      to a court appearance by the violator and which were marked â€œwarningâ€ as 
      a result of a court appearance.Â 
  

 On May 6, 2004, respondent was interviewed about the fifty-five additional 
  tickets and he stated the following:

  
    1. 
    
    Some of the violators were not known to respondent.Â  
      Respondent assumes these are tickets where the violator appeared in court 
      and the tickets were reduced to a warning in accordance with the customary 
      practice apparently acceptable to the City Police.Â 
    
  
  
    2.
    
    Some violators were known to respondent, but 
      he had noÂ  recollection of having dismissed the tickets outside court and, 
      therefore, assumes these violators appeared in court to contest the tickets.
      Â  
  
  
    3. 
     Ten violators were known to respondent and respondent 
      acknowledges he probably marked fifteen tickets issued to these violators 
      as â€œwarningsâ€ outside of court.Â  These tickets were issued to respondentâ€™s 
      relatives, employees, and his acquaintances. 
  

Of the seventy-six parking tickets examined by ODC, thirty-four were dismissed 
  by respondent outside of court.Â  
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent has violated the following Canons of the Code 
  of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold integrity 
  of the judiciary); Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the appearance 
  of impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply 
  with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence 
  in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary); Canon 2B (judge shall not 
  allow family, social, political or other relationships to influence the judge's 
  judicial conduct or judgment); Canon 3 (judge shall perform the duties of judicial 
  office impartially and diligently); and Canon 3(B)(7) (judge shall not initiate, 
  permit, or consider ex partecommunications, or consider other communications 
  made to the judge outside the presence of the parties concerning a pending proceeding).Â  
  By violating the Code of Judicial Conduct, respondent has also violated Rule 
  7(a)(1) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  

CONCLUSION 
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue a public reprimand. 
  [1] Â  Accordingly, respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct.Â  

PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


 
   [1]  
    As previously noted, a public reprimand is the most severe sanction the Court 
    can impose when a judge no longer holds judicial office.Â  See In 
    re Gravely, 321 S.C. 235, 467 S.E.2d 924 (1996).

title: Durham v. Vinson
description: The Court reviewed several issues raised on appeal in a medical malpractice case, including the following issues:  (1) whether the court erred in allowing testimony during the liability phase of trial regarding a hospital privileging file; (2) whether the court erred in its jury charge concerning the standard of care in a medical malpractice action; and (3) whether the court erred in allowing certain testimony to be admitted during the punitive damages phase of the trial.  The Court affirmed in part and reversed in part.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        Nellie Durham, Respondent-Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        David Vinson, Jr., M.D. and Upstate General Surgery, P.A., Appellants-Respondents.
      
    
  


On Appeal from Oconee County
  Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25872
  Heard September 24, 2003 - Filed September 13, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART

 
   
     
      
        Alexander M. Sanders, Jr., of Charleston; O. Doyle Martin, Jack H. 
          Tedards, Jr., Russell D. Ghent, and Seann A. Gray, all of Leatherwood 
          Walker Todd & Mann, P.C., of Greenville, for Appellants-Respondents.
        Chad Alan McGowan, of McGowan & Hood, of Rock Hill; F. Patrick 
          Hubbard, of Columbia; and Joseph G. Wright, III, of Wright Law Offices, 
          of Anderson, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  We are asked to rule 
  on several issues regarding alleged errors made during a medical malpractice 
  trial.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
Factual/Procedural Background
Respondent-Appellant, Nellie Durham (Durham), was 
  referred to Appellant-Respondent, Dr. David Vinson (Dr. Vinson), for a surgical 
  evaluation after being diagnosed with acid reflux and a hiatal hernia.Â  On October 
  26, 1996, Dr. Vinson attempted to repair the hernia by performing a laparoscopic 
  Nissen fundoplication (LNF)â€”an advanced form of laparoscopic surgery.Â  During 
  the LNF, Dr. Vinson did not â€œtake downâ€ the short gastric vessels, which would 
  have prevented the repair from being too tight. 
Initially, Durham appeared to respond well to the surgery, but then she began 
  to have trouble swallowing and began to vomit.Â  An esophagram, performed on 
  October 28, revealed that food particles were dispersed throughout the esophagus 
  and that the esophagus was not completely clearing the barium used in the esophagram.Â  
  As a result, Dr. Vinson performed an esophageal gastroduodenoscopy (EGD) on 
  Durham the next day.Â  During the EGD, Durhamâ€™s gag reflex was suppressed.Â  Whether 
  Durham aspirated [1]  during this 
  procedure or during the repair surgery conducted the next day became an issue 
  at trial.Â  It was clear, however, that Durham aspirated while under the care 
  of Dr. Vinson, and that, most likely, this aspiration occurred during the EGD.
On October 30, Dr. Vinson performed a repair LNF on Durham.Â  During this surgery, 
  Dr. Vinson took down the short gastric vessels.Â  Dr. Vinson also instructed 
  Diane Hardy, a Certified Registered Nurse Anesthetist, to advance a dilator 
  down Durhamâ€™s esophagus during the surgery, even though Hardy protested three 
  times that it was too tight.Â  Hardy followed Dr. Vinsonâ€™s orders and, as a result, 
  Durhamâ€™s esophagus was perforated.Â  When the perforation occurred, Dr. Vinson 
  switched from performing the procedure laparoscopically to performing an open 
  procedure in order to repair the perforation.
After the repair LNF surgery, Durham could not breathe without mechanical assistance 
  and was transferred to the Critical Care Unit (CCU) at Oconee Hospital.Â  Durhamâ€™s 
  family did not learn Durham had aspirated and her esophagus had been perforated 
  until Durham was later moved to Greenville Memorial Hospital.Â  Dr. Vinson informed 
  the family that everything had gone well and that she was only in CCU as a precaution.
While Durham was in CCU, her family requested that Dr. Vinson consult a pulmonologist.Â  
  However, he did not do so.Â  Durhamâ€™s family also requested that she be moved 
  to Greenville Memorial Hospital, a better-equipped facility, but Dr. Vinson 
  advised against the transfer because he believed that she could be properly 
  cared for at Oconee Hospital.Â  Finally, after two days, the family obtained 
  the transfer order from a nurse.Â  Durham entered Greenville Memorial Hospital 
  and remained there for over two months, with her first month being spent in 
  the CCU.
As a result of Dr. Vinsonâ€™s treatment, Durham developed adult respiratory distress 
  syndrome and later, due to the complications stemming from her aspiration, developed 
  pulmonary fibrosis.Â  At present, Durham can only walk for very short distances 
  and requires supplemental oxygen twenty-four hours a day.
Durham brought a medical malpractice action against Dr. Vinson.Â  After the 
  liability phase of the bifurcated trial, 
  [2]  the jury found Dr. Vinson was liable to Durham for $2,250,000 in actual 
  damages, and the jury found his conduct to be willful, wanton, or in reckless 
  disregard of Durhamâ€™s rights.Â  The trial then proceeded to the punitive damages 
  phase.Â  The jury awarded Durham $15,000,000 in punitive damages.
Following post-trial motions, the trial court found the award did not violate 
  Dr. Vinsonâ€™s due process rights, but remitted the award to $8,000,000 on the 
  basis the award was merely liberal.
Dr. Vinson appeals the trial court decision, raising the following 
  issues:

  
    I. 
    Did the trial court err by allowing testimony during the liabilityÂ Â  
      phase regarding Dr. Vinsonâ€™s hospital privileging file?
  
  
    II. 
    Did the trial court err by giving the jury a charge during 
      the liability phase that contained an incorrect discussion of the standard 
      of care in a medical malpractice action?
  
  
    III. 
    Did the trial court err by allowing, in the punitive damages 
      phase, the admission of evidence that Dr. Vinson prescribed valium to Durhamâ€™s 
      daughter?
  

Law/Analysis
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Hospital Privileging File
Dr. Vinson argues Durhamâ€™s counsel should not have 
  been allowed to question him about his failure to produce only a portion of 
  his hospital privileging file and then further prejudice him by mentioning this 
  failure in closing argument.Â  We agree but find the error harmless.Â  
The hospital privileging file contains information 
  related to a doctorâ€™s attempt to acquire certain privileges at the hospital, 
  such as the privilege to perform an LNF.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-71-20 (2001) provides, in part, as follows:

  All proceedings of and all data and information acquired by the committee 
    referred to in Section 40-71-10 
    [3]  in the exercise of its duties are confidential . . .Â  These proceedings 
    and documents are not subject to discovery, subpoena, or introduction into 
    evidence in any civil action . . . Information, documents, or records which 
    are otherwise available from original sources are not immune from discovery 
    or use in a civil action merely because they were presented during the committee 
    proceedings nor shall any complainant or witness before the committee be prevented 
    from testifying in a civil action as to matters of which he has knowledge 
    apart from the committee proceedings . . . .

The overriding public policy of the confidentiality statute is to encourage 
  health care professionals to monitor the competency and professional conduct 
  of their peers to safeguard and improve the quality of patient care.Â  McGee 
  v. Bruce Hosp. Sys., 312 S.C. 58, 61, 439 S.E.2d 257, 259 (1993).Â  The underlying 
  purpose behind the confidentiality statute is not to facilitate the prosecution 
  of civil actions, but to promote complete candor and open discussion among participants 
  in the peer review process.Â  Id.Â  In McGee, we further noted:

  The policy of encouraging full candor in peer review proceedings is advanced 
    only if all documents considered by the committee . . . during the peer review 
    or credentialing process are protected.Â  Committee members and those providing 
    information to the committee must be able to operate without fear of reprisal.Â  
    Similarly, it is essential that doctors seeking hospital privileges disclose 
    all pertinent information to the committee.Â  Physicians who fear that information 
    provided in an application might someday be used against them by a third party 
    will be reluctant to fully detail matters that the committee should consider.

Id. at 61-62, 439 S.E.2d at 259-260 (quoting 
  Cruger v. Love, 599 So.2d 111 (Fla. 1992)).
We concluded, however, that the outcome of the decision-making process is not 
  protected from discovery.Â  Therefore, a plaintiff is entitled to know the clinical 
  privileges either granted or denied by the hospital.Â  Id. at 63, 439 
  S.E.2d at 260-261.
During Durhamâ€™s direct examination of Dr. Vinson, 
  Dr. Vinson was asked about Durhamâ€™s medical records and the fact that they are 
  confidential.Â  He was also asked about the fact that Durham complied with his 
  request that she disclose her medical records.Â  Dr. Vinson was then asked:Â  
  â€œCorrespondingly we requested that you provide us with the application and supporting 
  documents.â€Â  Dr. Vinsonâ€™s counsel objected and a discussion ensued outside the 
  hearing of the jury. 
Dr. Vinson argued that the privileging file was confidential under McGee 
  and section 40-71-20 and that Durham was trying to create the impression that 
  he had something to hide.
The trial court found Dr. Vinson could be asked about the privileging file 
  but that the questions should be limited to whether Dr. Vinson authorized his 
  attorneys to disclose the results of the privileging file. [4] 
The testimony then continued with Durhamâ€™s counsel asking Dr. Vinson whether 
  he was aware that his privileging file was confidential and could not be disclosed 
  without his consent.Â  Dr. Vinson responded yes to the questions.Â  Then, the 
  following exchange occurred:
 
  Q:Â  And we on behalf of Mrs. Durham requested that you fully disclose the 
    results of your [privileging] file . . . however you only allowed the disclosure 
    of part of that file, is that correct?
  
    Mr. Gray:Â  Your Honor -
      The Court:Â  Yes sir.
      Mr. Gray:Â  Again I think thatâ€™s not a correct statement.
      The Court:Â  . . . Iâ€™m going to overrule your objection . . .
  

. . .
 
  Q:Â Â  On behalf of . . . Durham we requested your entireâ€”that you fully disclose 
    the results of your . . . [privileging] file but you only authorized a portion 
    of that file to be produced, is that correct?
  A:Â  Correct.

On cross-examination by his counsel, Dr. Vinson stated there were no results 
  of the privileging process that were adverse to him.
During closing argument, Durhamâ€™s counsel stated:

  Let me mention about privileges.Â  It is true that Dr. Vinson was privileged 
    by Oconee Memorial Hospital to perform this surgery.Â  It is also true that 
    Dr. Vinson was privileged to perform surgical critical care.Â  Dr. Vinson submitted 
    certain information to Oconee Memorial Hospital.Â  One of the things he submitted 
    was a resume or what is referred to as a Curriculum Vitae.Â  This was submitted.Â  
    He had a fellowship, surgical critical care.Â  Is there anywhere on that sheet 
    that says that critical care fellowship was unaccredited?Â  No.Â  Had it been, 
    would that have made a difference?Â  I donâ€™t know.Â  We havenâ€™t seen the 
    file but I think thatâ€™s an important deception.Â  The second thing Iâ€™d 
    like to point out is I donâ€™t know what Dr. Vinson told them about his training 
    in residency.Â  If he told them what was in the sworn statement to you ladies 
    and gentlemen of the jury, he did not have proctoring and under the regulations 
    he would have to have it or did he tell what he told his expert when he put 
    him on the standâ€”Iâ€™ve been trained.Â  I donâ€™t know.Â  If he told them something 
    that wasnâ€™t true they would have given privileges.

(emphases added).Â  Durhamâ€™s counsel also stated, 
  â€œHe has tried to deceive everyone throughout this litigation and now heâ€™s trying 
  to commit the ultimate sin and thatâ€™s to deceive you ladies and gentlemen of 
  the jury.â€
The trial court erred by allowing Durhamâ€™s counsel to ask Dr. Vinson about 
  his failure to fully disclose his privileging file, a file that he was under 
  no obligation to disclose pursuant to section 40-71-20.Â  If physicians can be 
  questioned before the jury about the refusal to produce this privileged information, 
  the effect is to pressure them toward disclosure of the privileging file.Â  As 
  occurred here, the exercise of the statutory right not to disclose the information 
  would be used against the physician as evidence the physician is hiding something.Â  
  Allowing this to occur does not serve the policy goals of promoting candor and 
  open discussion among participants in the peer review process.Â  See McGee, 
  312 S.C. at 62, 439 S.E.2d at 259 (participants in the peer review process must 
  be able to operate without fear of reprisal).
This error was exacerbated when counsel effectively argued that Dr. Vinson 
  had deceived everyone by failing to disclose the file.Â  The fact that Dr. Vinson 
  was able to tell the jury that he had no adverse results during the privileging 
  process did not cure the error.Â  The jury was not informed that Dr. Vinson was 
  not obligated to produce his privileging file by statute.Â  Instead, the jury 
  was allowed to believe Dr. Vinson was not forthcoming for some unstated reason 
  and, as a result, the jury may have believed Dr. Vinson was attempting to conceal 
  something in the file.
However, we find the error harmless.Â  First, there was other properly admitted 
  evidence that indicated Dr. Vinson was being deceitful, such as (1) failing 
  to indicate his fellowship program was unaccredited on his curriculum vitae, 
  (2) telling Durhamâ€™s family that Durham was fine and had only been placed in 
  the CCU as a precaution, (3) failing to call a specialist upon the familyâ€™s 
  request, (4) misinforming his own expert about the training he had in performing 
  a LNF, and (5) attempting to shift the blame for Durhamâ€™s aspiration on another 
  doctor.
Second, the evidence of Dr. Vinsonâ€™s liability is overwhelming.Â  The breach 
  of his duty of care to Durham is uncontradicted, especially in light of the 
  fact that his own expert believed Dr. Vinsonâ€™s treatment of Durham had deviated 
  from the standard of care.
II.Â Â  Jury Charge on Standard of Care
As to the standard of care, the court charged the 
  jury as follows:

  A physician or surgeon who undertakes to render professional services must 
    meet these requirements.Â  The physician must possess the degree of professional 
    learning, skill and ability which others similarly situat[ed] ordinarily 
    possess at the time.Â  The physician must exercise reasonable care and diligence 
    in the application of this knowledge and skill to the patientâ€™s care and the 
    physician must use his best judgment in the treatment and care of his patient. 
    â€¦ If the physician fails in any of those particulars and such failure is the 
    proximate cause of injury and damage the physician is liable. 

(emphasis added).Â  The court again charged that 
  a physician â€œshall possess and exercise that degree of knowledge, care and skill 
  ordinarily possessed by members of his profession in good standing under the 
  same or similar circumstances.â€ 
Dr. Vinson argues the knowledge component should not have been included in 
  the charge.Â  He contends that Durhamâ€™s repeated emphasis on his education and 
  training, combined with the trial judgeâ€™s charge, created the impression the 
  jury could find Dr. Vinson liable for malpractice solely on the basis of a lack 
  of education or background, that is, if they found he did not â€œpossess the degree 
  of professional learningâ€ that he should have, regardless of his conduct in 
  treating Durham.Â  We disagree.
To the extent that the trial courtâ€™s charge suggests that a lack of professional 
  learning, by itself, constitutes a breach of the standard of care, the charge 
  was erroneous.Â  The standard of care in a medical malpractice action concerns 
  both the physicianâ€™s skill and the physicianâ€™s professional learning.Â  
  Accordingly, the appropriate standard of care charge is the following:Â  A physician 
  is only bound to possess and exercise that degree of skill and learning 
  that is ordinarily possessed and exercised by members of his profession in good 
  standing acting in the same or similar circumstances.Â  King v. Williams, 
  276 S.C. 478, 482, 279 S.E.2d 618, 620 (1981) (degree of care which must be 
  observed is that of an average, competent practitioner acting in same or similar 
  circumstances); Bessinger v. DeLoach, 230 S.C. 1, 7, 94 S.E.2d 3, 6 (1956) 
  (physician has been held to degree of skill and learning which is ordinarily 
  possessed and exercised by members of his profession in good standing in the 
  same general neighborhood or in similar localities). [5] Â  
Professional learning is pertinent to a physicianâ€™s 
  background and training, particularly when the procedure in questionâ€”such as 
  the one performed in the present caseâ€”requires a special kind of learning.Â  
  Therefore, the knowledge component was properly included in the jury charge.Â  
  But the lack of or inadequacy of such knowledge is not, by itself, dispositive 
  as to whether a physician is liable for medical malpractice.Â  Therefore, the 
  portion of the charge instructing the jury to find the physician liable if he 
  â€œfails in any of those particulars and such failure is the proximate 
  cause of injury and damage,â€ was erroneous.Â  We note that this is a minor judicial 
  error in an otherwise appropriate charge.Â Â Â  
Nonetheless, we find the error harmless given that 
  Dr. Vinsonâ€™s liability to Durham is so clear.Â  As noted previously, it is uncontradicted 
  that Dr. Vinson committed a gross breach of the standard of care in more than 
  one instance while treating Durham.
III.Â Â Â  Valium Prescription Evidence
Dr. Vinson argues he is entitled to a new trial 
  due to the admission of evidence, during the punitive damages phase of the bifurcated 
  trial, that he prescribed valium to Durhamâ€™s daughter and that he instructed 
  her to give the valium to other family members.Â  We agree.
Durhamâ€™s daughter testified Dr. Vinson told her 
  that she and her sisters were upsetting Durham while she was in the CCU.Â  She 
  stated that he wrote her a prescription for sixty valiums, and told her to take 
  them and pass them around to the other sisters to calm them down.Â  The daughter 
  stated that she was never a patient of Dr. Vinsonâ€™s.Â  Another daughter corroborated 
  this testimony.Â Â Â  
In addition, a portion of the deposition of Dr. 
  Vincent Russo, an expert for Durham, was admitted during the punitive damages 
  phase.Â  Dr. Russo testified regarding the valium prescription incident.Â  The 
  court overruled defense counselâ€™s objection on the basis the evidence was relevant 
  to the Gamble [6]  factor concerning Dr. Vinsonâ€™s 
  awareness or concealment.Â  The court further stated the evidence did not violate 
  Rule 403, SCRE. [7] 
Dr. Russo testified Dr. Vinson attempted to alleviate the familyâ€™s anxiety 
  about Durham by prescribing valium to Durhamâ€™s daughter and telling her to distribute 
  the valium to the other relatives.Â  Dr. Russo opined that a reasonable surgeon 
  does not engage in such conduct and that his actions were incompetent and could 
  be criminal and unethical.
We find that the trial court erroneously allowed the valium prescription evidence.Â  
  The evidence was inappropriate because it concerned Dr. Vinsonâ€™s misconduct 
  towards a third party, rather than his misconduct towards Durham.Â  We disagree 
  with the trial courtâ€™s finding that the evidence was relevant to the Gamble 
  factor of concealment.Â  The finding that the evidence is relevant to whether 
  Dr. Vinson attempted to conceal his misconduct towards Durham is attenuated.Â  
  Further, the evidence is inflammatory, especially in light of the fact that 
  the valium prescription evidence was the only evidence admitted during the punitive 
  damages phase.Â  We find the evidence violates Rule 403, SCRE, because the prejudicial 
  effect of the evidence outweighs any probative value it may have had.Â  By allowing 
  the evidence, the trial court allowed the jury to punish Dr. Vinson for a bad 
  act unrelated to his actions towards Durham.Â  See State Farm Mut. 
  Auto. Ins. Co. v. Campbell, 538 U.S. 408, 409, 123 S. Ct. 1513, 1515 (2003) 
  (defendantâ€™s dissimilar acts, independent from acts upon which liability was 
  premised, may not serve as basis for punitive damages; defendant should be punished 
  for conduct that harmed plaintiff, not for being an unsavory individual).
Accordingly, we reverse the trial court on this ground and remand the case 
  for a new punitive damages phase. 
Conclusion
We find the trial court committed two errors during the liability phase of 
  trial.Â  The trial court erred by allowing Durhamâ€™s counsel to ask Dr. Vinson 
  about his failure to fully disclose his privileging file and by giving an inappropriate 
  standard of care charge to the jury.Â  But we find the errors harmless given 
  that Dr. Vinsonâ€™s liability to Durham is so clear based on the uncontradicted 
  evidence that Dr. Vinson committed a gross breach of the standard of care in 
  more than one instance while treating Durham.
We further find the admission of the valium prescription evidence during the 
  punitive damages phase violates Rule 403, SCRE.Â  Because this error was not 
  harmless, we reverse the trial court and remand the case for a new punitive 
  damages phase.
The following issues raised by Appellants-Respondents are not preserved for 
  review:Â  Issues I, V, VII, XI, and XIII.Â  See Bakala v. Bakala, 
  352 S.C. 612, 576 S.E.2d 156 (2003) (due process claim raised for first time 
  on appeal is not preserved); Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 570 S.E.2d 
  176 (2002) (to preserve issue for appellate review, issue must have been raised 
  to and ruled upon by trial court); Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 
  479 S.E.2d 35 (1996) (party may not argue one ground for objection at trial 
  and another ground on appeal); Varnadore v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 
  289 S.C. 155, 345 S.E.2d 711 (1986) (proper course is to object immediately 
  to improper argument).
Appellants-Respondentsâ€™ remaining issues are without merit and we affirm pursuant 
  to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Issue II:Â  Gamble 
  v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 406 S.E.2d 350 (1991); Issue VI:Â  Rule 803(4) 
  and 803(6), SCRE; Issues VIII and IX:Â  Elledge v. Richland/Lexington Sch. 
  Dist. Five, 352 S.C. 179, 573 S.E.2d 789 (2002) (admission of testimony 
  largely within trial courtâ€™s sound discretion, exercise of which will not be 
  disturbed on appeal absent abuse of discretion).Â  Respondent-Appellantâ€™s issue 
  is also without merit and we affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the 
  following authority:Â  Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali Ins. Co., 
  321 S.C. 1, 466 S.E.2d 727 (1996) (grant of motion is within trial courtâ€™s discretion, 
  and absent abuse of discretion, it will not be reversed on appeal).
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
WALLER, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., 
  concur.


 
   
    [1]  An aspiration refers to the accidental sucking in of food particles 
    or fluids into the lungs. 

 
   
    [2]  Trial judges have discretion as to whether to bifurcate a trial.Â  
    Rule 42(b), SCRCP; Senter v. Piggly Wiggly Carolina Co., 341 S.C. 74, 
    77, 533 S.E.2d 575, 577 (2000).Â  Although some states require bifurcation 
    in every case in which the plaintiff seeks punitive damages, we are unwilling 
    to impose such a requirement.Â  We encourage judges, however, to bifurcate 
    trials in complex medical malpractice cases such as this one, particularly 
    when bifurcation helps to clarify and simplify the issues.Â  Nonetheless, in 
    exercising their discretion, trial judges must continue to heed the â€œseparate 
    issueâ€ mandate of Rule 42(b); see also Flagstar Corp. v. Royal Surplus 
    Lines, 341 S.C. 68, 73, 533 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2000) (trial judges are responsible 
    for determining whether trial issues are distinct enough to warrant severability).

 
   
    [3]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-71-10 (2001) (members of certain professional 
    committees exempt from tort liability). 

 
   [4]  Durham argues and the 
    trial court found that Dr. Vinson opened the door to asking questions about 
    the privileging file during his opening argument.Â  In opening, counsel stated:


  Dr. Vinson was a fully licensed physician, authorized by South 
    Carolina law to practice medicine and to practice surgery.Â  Board certification 
    was not required for Dr. Vinson to get his privileges to practice surgery 
    including doing the [LNF].Â  Dr. Vinson presented his information to the credentials 
    accrediting authorities at Oconee Memorial Hospital and was given the authority 
    to do the procedures he did on Ms. Durham.Â  He was not required to be Board 
    certified.


  This did not, however, open the door to the evidence.Â  Because Durhamâ€™s counsel 
    emphasized in opening argument that Dr. Vinson was not board certified in 
    surgery, Dr. Vinson simply desired to point out in his opening that, although 
    he was not board certified, he was in fact privileged by Oconee Hospital to 
    perform surgery.Â  Further, the information Dr. Vinson relayed to the jury 
    only concerned the results of the privileging process.

 
   [5] This Court eventually 
    eliminated the phrase, known as the locality rule, â€œin the same general neighborhood 
    or in similar localitiesâ€ and replaced it with the phrase, â€œacting in same 
    or similar circumstances.â€Â  King, 276 S.C. at 482, 279 S.E.2d at 620.

 
   
    [6]  Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 111-112, 406 S.E.2d 350, 
    354 (1991), set out the factors to be used when conducting a review of a punitive 
    damage award.Â  The factors are:Â  (1) defendantâ€™s degree of culpability; (2) 
    duration of the conduct; (3) defendantâ€™s awareness or concealment; (4) the 
    existence of similar past conduct; (5) likelihood the award will deter the 
    defendant or others from like conduct; (6) whether the award is reasonably 
    related to the harm likely to result from such conduct; (7) defendantâ€™s ability 
    to pay; and finally, (8) other factors deemed appropriate. 


   
    [7] Rule 403, SCRE, states:Â  â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded 
    if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair 
    prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations 
    of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€

title: McCormick County Council v. Butler
description: In this opinion, the Court held, in its original jurisdiction, that the McCormick County Clerk of Court, not the County Council, has the authority to assign offices in the county courthouse and possess the keys to those offices.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
 
   
     
      
        McCormick County Council, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Kathryne P. Butler, in her capacity as McCormick County Clerk of Court, 
          Respondent. 
      
    
  


IN THE ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No. 25873
  Submitted August 18, 2004 - Filed September 13, 2004

 
   
     
      
        George P. Callison, Jr., Callison Dorn Thomason & Knott, PA, of 
          Greenwood, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Deputy Attorney General Steve Lynch, Assistant Deputy 
          Attorney General Robert Cook and Assistant Attorney General Tracey Green, 
          all of Columbia, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner (County Council) seeks a declaratory 
  judgment in this Courtâ€™s original jurisdiction to have the Court determine who 
  has the right to assign office space and possess the keys to the offices in 
  the McCormick County Courthouse.Â  Because this is a matter of significant public 
  interest, we grant the petition to hear this matter in our original jurisdiction, 
  dispense with further briefing, and hold that respondent (the Clerk of Court) 
  has the authority to assign offices and possess the keys thereto in the county 
  courthouse.Â  
In an administrative order dated June 23, 2004, Chief Justice Toal ordered 
  that, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-17-210 (1976), the Clerk of Court has 
  charge of the courthouse and has the authority to exercise control over the 
  assignment of rooms and possess all office keys.Â  County Council asks that this 
  administrative order be stayed pending resolution of this matter.Â  The request 
  to stay the June 23rd administrative order is denied.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 4-1-80 (1986) requires the governing body of each 
  county to furnish the probate judge, auditor, superintendent of education, clerk 
  of court, sheriff, treasurer and master in equity office room, furniture, and 
  stationery, as well as fuel, lights, postage and other incidentals necessary 
  to transact business.Â  In addition, the county governing body is required to 
  make any alterations and additions advisable or necessary to any courthouse.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-17-60 (1986).
The office of clerk of court is an elected one, created by Article V, Â§ 24 
  of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  This section states that the General Assembly 
  shall provide for the clerk of courtâ€™s duties.Â  In S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-17-210 
  (1976), the General Assembly has provided that the county clerk of court has 
  charge of the courthouse and must open the courthouse when required for public 
  use and close it at all other times.Â  
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-650 (1986) provides that the county administrator 
  has no authority over elected officials of the county whose offices are created 
  by the Constitution or general law of the State.
Although the statutes do not specifically provide who has the authority to 
  assign offices and possess the keys thereto in the county courthouse, the provision 
  of Â§ 14-17-210 giving the clerk of court charge of the courthouse must include 
  the assignment of offices and possession of keys.Â  Further, since Â§ 4-9-650 
  specifically states that the county administrator does not have authority over 
  elected officials whose offices are created by the Constitution, the county 
  has no authority to control the Clerk of Court.
Essentially, County Council is challenging the Chief Justiceâ€™s June 23rd 
  administrative order in this matter.Â  As the administrative head of the unified 
  judicial system, [1]  the Chief 
  Justice has the authority to issue administrative orders controlling the courts 
  in the State.Â  Because authority to control the courthouse is given to the Clerk 
  of Court, we hold that the Clerk of Court has the authority to assign offices 
  in and possess the keys to the offices in the courthouse.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  MOORE, J., not 
  participating.


 
   [1]  S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 4.
