title: State v. Missouri
description: The Court reversed the court of appealsâ€™ decision and held that the Petitioner had a reasonable expectation of privacy in anotherâ€™s apartment and therefore could challenge the search under the Fourth Amendment.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Victor Missouri, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF
CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Greenville County
Â H. Dean Hall, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25874
Heard June 8, 2004 - Filed September 
  27, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of South 
  Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark 
  Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: This Court 
  granted certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision reversing the trial 
  court, which held that Petitioner Victor Missouri (Missouri) did not have a 
  reasonable expectation of privacy in anotherâ€™s apartment and therefore could 
  not challenge the search of the apartment under the Fourth Amendment.Â  We reverse.
Factual/Procedural Background
In early 1995, Greenville detectives were investigating 
  a crack-cocaine ring.Â  The police obtained a warrant to search the apartment 
  of Curtis and Laura Sibert (Siberts) for cocaine.Â  Missouri was in the apartment 
  at the time, standing near a quantity of crack cocaine.Â  Missouri was arrested 
  and charged with trafficking in crack cocaine.Â  
At trial, lead detective Eric Cureton (Detective 
  Cureton) admitted that he lied in the affidavit issued in support of the search 
  warrant.Â  In addition, Missouri argued that exculpatory information was omitted 
  from the affidavit.Â  Nonetheless, the trial court denied Missouriâ€™s motion to 
  suppress the evidence obtained in the search.Â  In an unpublished opinion, the 
  court of appeals reversed, ruling that the omitted information was necessary 
  for the magistrateâ€™s finding of probable cause, and remanded the matter for 
  a hearing to determine whether Missouri had a reasonable expectation of privacy 
  in the Sibertsâ€™ apartment.Â  State v. Missouri, Op. No. 97-UP-448 (S.C. 
  Ct. App. filed September 15, 1997).Â  This Court affirmed the court of appealsâ€™ 
  ruling, holding that the search warrant was invalid because it was not supported 
  by probable cause.Â  State v. Missouri, 337 S.C. 548, 556-557, 524 S.E.2d 
  394, 398 (1999).Â Â Â Â Â Â  
A hearing was then held to determine, as the court of appeals 
  instructed, whether Missouri had a reasonable expectation of privacy in the 
  Sibertsâ€™ apartment.Â  Missouri and Curtis Sibert (Curtis) testified that they 
  are close friends and have known each other for many years.Â  On occasion, Curtis 
  would give Missouri a key to the Sibertsâ€™ apartment, allowing Missouri to come 
  and go as he pleased.Â  Even though Missouri lived only a few miles away, he 
  would stay at the Sibertsâ€™ apartment whenever he wanted to â€œget away.â€Â  Missouri 
  testified that the apartment was a place of comfort and solace for him and that 
  he felt a sense of privacy there.Â Â Â  
The State presented the testimony of the arresting 
  officer, Detective Cureton.Â  When Detective Cureton conducted surveillance on 
  the Sibertsâ€™ apartment the day of the arrest, he observed Missouri enter the 
  apartment between 2:30 and 3:00 p.m.Â  Detective Cureton also observed Curtis 
  and his wife Laura purchasing large quantities of baking soda 
  [1]  at different locations around town earlier that day. The police searched 
  the Sibertsâ€™ apartment between 9:30 and 10:00 p.m.
When he entered the apartment, 
  Detective Cureton discovered Missouri in the kitchen standing over several dishes 
  of cooling crack cocaine, while Curtis and Laura sat on the couch watching television.Â  
  Detective Cureton testified that the police confiscated Missouriâ€™s keys and 
  that the key ring held only three keys: two car keys and a key to Missouriâ€™s 
  residence.Â  In addition, Detective Cureton recovered a black bag belonging to 
  Missouri that contained scales and packaging paper.Â  Detective Cureton testified 
  that Missouri had no other items in the apartment.Â  But on cross-examination, 
  Detective Cureton admitted that he did not know whether Missouri had a change 
  of clothes in the Sibertsâ€™ apartment at the time of the search.Â  
Curtis testified that Missouri 
  did not stay over the night before the search took place and could not remember 
  the last time Missouri had spent the night.Â  Curtis testified that at the time 
  of arrest, (1) Missouri had a key to the apartment; (2) he would not have allowed 
  Missouri to use the apartment if he had known Missouri intended to mix drugs 
  there; and (3) Missouri was in the apartment for social reasons only.
After considering the testimony 
  presented at the hearing, the trial judge found Missouri had a reasonable expectation 
  of privacy in the Sibertsâ€™ apartment.Â  The court of appeals reversed, holding 
  that Missouri did not have â€œstandingâ€ [2]  because he did not have a reasonable expectation 
  of privacy in the Sibertsâ€™ apartment.Â  Missouri was merely a permitted guest 
  conducting business, the court ruled, not an overnight guest entitled to Fourth 
  Amendment protection.Â  State v. Missouri, 572 S.E.2d 467, 471, 352 S.C. 
  121, 130 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â 
This Court granted Missouriâ€™s petition for writ 
  of certiorari to review the following question:

Did the court of appeals err in reversing the trial 
  judgeâ€™s ruling that Missouri had a reasonable expectation of privacy in the 
  Sibertsâ€™ apartment?

Law/Analysis
Standard 
  of Review
When reviewing a Fourth Amendment search and seizure 
  case, an appellate court must affirm the trial judgeâ€™s ruling if there is any 
  evidence to support the ruling.Â  State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 66, 
  528 S.E.2d 661, 666 (2000) (emphasis added).Â  The appellate court will 
  reverse only when there is clear error.Â  Id.
Reasonable 
  Expectation of Privacy
Missouri argues that he had a reasonable 
  expectation of privacy in the Sibertsâ€™ apartment at the time the police searched 
  the apartment.Â  We agree.
The Fourth Amendment guarantees individuals the 
  right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  U.S. Const. amend. 
  IV; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10.Â  To claim protection under the Fourth Amendment 
  of the U.S. Constitution, defendants must show that they have a legitimate expectation 
  of privacy in the place searched.Â  Rakas v. Illinois, 439 U.S. 128, 143, 
  99 S. Ct. 421, 430 (1978).Â  A legitimate expectation of privacy is both subjective 
  and objective in nature: the defendant must show (1) he had a subjective expectation 
  of not being discovered, and (2) the expectation is one that society recognizes 
  as reasonable.Â  Oliver v. United States, 466 U.S. 170, 177, 104 S. Ct. 
  1735, 1741 (1984) (citing Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347, 361, 88 
  S. Ct. 507, 516 (1967) (Harlan, J., concurring)).Â  
At the â€œvery coreâ€ of the Fourth Amendment is a 
  personâ€™s right â€œto retreat into his own home and there be free from unreasonable 
  government intrusions.â€Â  Kyllo v. United States, 533 U.S. 27, 31, 121 
  S. Ct. 2038, 2041 (2001) (citation omitted).Â  What is less clear is whether 
  a person has a legitimate expectation of privacy in the home of another.Â  Three 
  cases from the United States Supreme Court (USSC) provide guidance in our consideration 
  of this question.Â  
When first presented with this question, the USSC 
  held that a defendant could challenge a search under the Fourth Amendment simply 
  by being â€œlegitimately on the premises.â€ Jones v. United States, 362 
  U.S. 257, 267, 80 S. Ct. 725, 734 (1960), overruled in part, United 
  States v. Salvucci, 448 U.S. 83, 89, 100 S. Ct. 2547, 2551 (1980) (rejecting 
  the â€œautomatic standingâ€ rule, which conferred standing to any defendant charged 
  with crimes of possession). Â The standard of simply being â€œlegitimately on the 
  premisesâ€ was eventually repudiated as being â€œtoo broad a gauge for measurement 
  of Fourth Amendment rights.â€Â  Rakas v. Illinois, 439 U.S. 128, 142, 99 
  S. Ct. 421, 429 (1978).Â  Nonetheless, the Rakas Court did â€œnot question 
  the conclusion of Jones that the defendant in that case suffered a violation 
  of his personal Fourth Amendment rights.â€Â  Id. at 141, 99 S. Ct. at 429.Â  
  In affirming the ultimate conclusion of Jones, the Court was persuaded 
  by the following facts:Â  (1) Jones and the owner of the apartment were friends; 
  (2) the owner had given Jones a key to the apartment; (3) Jones had a suit and 
  shirt in the apartment;Â  (4) Jones had slept there at least once before; and 
  (5) Jones was the sole occupant of the apartment at the time it was searched.Â  
  Id. Â Accordingly, the Court agreed that the defendant was entitled to 
  Fourth Amendment protection.Â  Id.
In a subsequent case, the USSC found that an overnight 
  guest had a reasonable expectation of privacy in anotherâ€™s home.Â  Minnesota 
  v. Olson, 495 U.S. 91, 110 S. Ct. 1684 (1990).Â  The defendant in Olson 
  was suspected of robbing a gas station and fatally wounding the station manager.Â  
  An investigation led the police to a house where they thought the suspect was 
  hiding.Â  When the police confirmed that the defendant was inside the upper unit 
  of the home, they drew their weapons, entered the duplex without the ownerâ€™s 
  permission, found the defendant hiding in a closet, and arrested him.Â  The Minnesota 
  Supreme Court held that the defendant had a â€œsufficient interestâ€ in the home 
  such that he could challenge the legality of the warrantless search and arrest.Â  
  Id. at 94, 110 S. Ct. at 1687.Â  
The USSC affirmed, concluding that the defendantâ€™s 
  status as an overnight guest was â€œalone enough to show that he had an expectation 
  of privacy in the home that society is prepared to recognize as reasonable.â€Â  
  Id. at 96, 110 S. Ct. at 1688.Â  Although the Court noted that the defendant 
  had been staying at the home, sleeping on the floor for several days before 
  the robbery, and had a change of clothes with him, the Court did not articulate 
  what constitutes an â€œovernightâ€ guest.Â  Id. at 97 n. 6, 110 S. Ct. 1688 
  n. 6.Â  Instead, the Court supported its holding by speaking generally about 
  the social expectations of privacy recognized by houseguests:Â  

From the overnight guestâ€™s perspective, he seeks shelter in 
  anotherâ€™s home precisely because it provides him with privacy, a place where 
  he and his possessions will not be disturbed by anyone but his host and those 
  his host allows inside.
â€¦
The houseguest is there with the permission of his host, who 
  is willing to share his house and his privacy with his guest.Â  

Id. at 99, 110 S. Ct. at 1690 (emphasis added).Â  
  Accordingly, the Court concluded that the defendantâ€™s expectation of privacy 
  in the home of another â€œwas rooted in â€˜understandings that are recognized and 
  permitted by society,â€™â€ and therefore the defendant was permitted to challenge 
  the search.Â  Id. at 100, 110 S. Ct. at 1690.Â  
Most recently, the USSC held that the defendants 
  did not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in the home of another when 
  the nature of the defendantâ€™s visit was purely commercial, the visit was short, 
  and there was no previous connection between the defendants and the lessee.Â  
  Minnesota v. Carter, 525 U.S. 83, 90, 119 S. Ct. 469, 473 (1998).Â  The 
  defendants in Carter lived out-of-state and used the lesseeâ€™s apartment 
  for the sole purpose of packaging cocaine.Â  The defendants had never visited 
  the apartment before and stayed for two-and-a-half hours.Â  In exchange for use 
  of the apartment, the defendants gave the lessee one-eighth ounce of cocaine.Â  
  The Court concluded that the defendants did not have a legitimate expectation 
  of privacy because they were â€œessentially present for a business transaction 
  and were only in the home a matter of hours.â€Â  Id. at 90, 119 S. Ct. 
  at 473.Â  In addition, the Court was persuaded by the fact that the defendants 
  had no â€œprevious relationshipâ€ with the lessee and nothing â€œto suggest a degree 
  of acceptance into the household.â€Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, in a 5-4 decision, 
  the Court held that the defendants were not entitled to Fourth Amendment protection. 
  [3] Â Â  
In the present case, Missouri 
  and Curtis testified that they had grown up together and were â€œgood friends.â€Â  
  Missouri had frequently visited the Sibertsâ€™ apartment in the past and occasionally 
  spent the night.Â  Missouri described the Sibert home as a place to â€œget awayâ€ 
  and as a place to â€œfind comfort.â€Â  At times, Missouri had a key to the Sibertsâ€™ 
  apartment and kept a change of clothes there.Â  He paid nothing to use the apartment 
  and was there for at least seven hours on the day of the search. 
By choosing to share the privacy of their home 
  with Missouri on several occasions in the past and on the occasion in question, 
  both the Siberts and Missouri demonstrated a subjective expectation of privacy, 
  and that expectation, we hold, is one that society is prepared to recognize 
  as reasonable.Â  See Oliver, 466 U.S. at 177, 104 S. Ct. at 1741 (citing 
  Katz, 389 U.S. at 361, 88 S. Ct. at 516 (Harlan, J., concurring) (a reasonable 
  expectation of privacy is both subjective and objective in nature)).Â  Moreover, 
  the trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact support his ruling that Missouriâ€™s expectation 
  of privacy in the Sibert home was reasonable.Â  See Brockman, 339 S.C. 
  at 66, 528 S.E.2d at 666 (an appellate court must affirm if there is any 
  evidence in the record supporting the trial judgeâ€™s ruling).Â  Therefore, 
  we reverse the court of appealsâ€™ decision.Â Â Â Â  Â 
Conclusion
For these reasons, we reverse the court 
  of appealsâ€™ decision and hold that Missouri had a reasonable expectation of 
  privacy in the Sibertsâ€™ apartment.Â  Missouri is therefore entitled to challenge 
  the search under the Fourth Amendment.Â  In addition, because we held in a prior 
  decision that the search warrant executed in this case was invalid, the evidence 
  seized must be suppressed and Missouriâ€™s conviction vacated. 
 MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Baking soda is used in transforming powdered cocaine into crack cocaine.

 
   
    [2]  The United States Supreme Court has expressly rejected the application 
    of an analysis based on the standing doctrine; instead, the analysis is based 
    on substantive Fourth Amendment law.Â  Rakas v. Illinois, 439 U.S. 128, 
    140, 99 S. Ct. 421, 429 (1978).Â  The use of the term â€œstandingâ€ has created 
    confusion in this context, and therefore â€œstandingâ€ is no longer appropriate 
    to â€œconnote the legitimate expectation of privacy in the evidence seized or 
    the premises searched.â€Â  United States v. Bouffard, 917 F.2d 673, 675 
    (1st Cir. 1990).Â  

 
   
    [3]  Although the majority in Carter held that the defendants were 
    not entitled to Fourth Amendment protection, a â€œdifferent majorityâ€ recognized 
    that social guests present for less than an overnight stay may enjoy a reasonable 
    expectation of privacy in their hostâ€™s home.Â  In a concurring opinion, Justice 
    Breyer explicitly stated that he agreed with the dissentâ€”which concluded that 
    all invited guests are entitled to Fourth Amendment protection, whether 
    present for a business purpose or notâ€”but he agreed with the majorityâ€™s decision 
    because he thought the search itself was lawful.Â  Id. at 104, 119 S. 
    Ct. at 480 (Breyer, J., concurring).Â  In another concurrence, Justice Kennedy 
    stated that, in his view, â€œalmost all social guests have a legitimate 
    expectation of privacy â€¦ in their hostâ€™s home.â€Â  Id. at 99, 119 S. 
    Ct. at 478 (Kennedy, J., concurring) (emphasis added).Â  But because the defendants 
    in Carter were not â€œguests,â€ they did not have an expectation of privacy 
    in the ownerâ€™s home.Â  Id. at 102, 119 S. Ct. at 479.Â  Accordingly, 
    it is apparent that at least five members of the Courtâ€”the three who dissented 
    and the two who concurredâ€”would be willing to extend protection to guests 
    present for social reasons and present for some time less than an overnight 
    stay.Â Â

text:
BENCH MEMORANDUM



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Elizabeth Darlene Dorrell, Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Transportation,
APAC-Carolina, Inc., and APAC-Georgia, Inc., Defendants,
Of whom APAC-Carolina, Inc. is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Georgetown County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25875
Heard October 21, 2003 - Filed September 
  27, 2004

REVERSED AND
REMANDED


  
    
      
Frank J. Bryan, of Floyd Law Firm, P.C., of Surfside Beach; 
  and J. Matthew Dove, of Dove Law Firm, of Murrells Inlet, for appellant.
Robert L. Widener, of McNair Law Firm, of Columbia; William 
  W. Doar, Jr., of McNair Law Firm, of Georgetown; and Peter Murnaghan, of Murnaghan 
  & Ferguson, of Tampa; Florida, for respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Elizabeth Darlene Dorrell 
  (Dorrell) appeals after the circuit court granted summary judgment to respondent 
  APAC-Carolina, Inc. (APAC).Â  This case was certified from the court of appeals 
  pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We reverse and remand.
Factual/Procedural Background
Dorrell was injured in a one-car accident on April 16, 1996.Â  
  Apparently a gust of wind caused Dorrellâ€™s car to veer to the right and drop 
  off the road onto the dirt shoulder, which was eleven to twelve inches below 
  the road surface.Â  Due to the drop, Dorrell lost control of her car, the car 
  rolled several times, and she was thrown from her car into a ditch twenty-five 
  to thirty feet away.Â  Dorrell suffered permanent injuries and incurred significant 
  medical bills.
The road had been recently repaved pursuant to a contract 
  between the paving company, APAC, and the South Carolina Department of Transportation 
  (SCDOT).Â  On April 22, 1996, six days after the accident, SCDOT issued an inspection 
  report, accepting APACâ€™s work and returning the highway to SCDOTâ€™s control.Â  
  In its report, SCDOT stated that it had â€œaccepted the highway back for State 
  maintenance as of November 17, 1995.â€
Dorrell sued APAC and SCDOT 
  [1]  on a negligence theory.Â  As to APAC, Dorrell alleged that APAC was 
  negligent for the following: (1) failing to perform the contract according to 
  its specifications; (2) creating a dangerous condition by raising the roadway 
  to a level of eleven to twelve inches above the shoulder; (3) failing to correct 
  the dangerous condition; (4) failing to warn motorists about the dangerous condition; 
  (5) failing to exercise the degree of care that a reasonable and prudent road 
  contractor would have exercised under the circumstances; (6) failing to inspect 
  the road and detect the dangerous condition.Â  As to SCDOT, Dorrell alleged that 
  SCDOT was negligent for the following:Â  (1) failing to warn motorists of the 
  dangerous condition; (2) failing to correct the dangerous condition; and (3) 
  failing to inspect the road upon completion of the resurfacing and detect the 
  dangerous condition which actually and proximately caused Dorrellâ€™s injuries.
Dorrell eventually settled with SCDOT, leaving APAC as the 
  sole defendant.Â  APAC denied liability and subsequently filed a motion for summary 
  judgment.Â  In support of its motion, APAC argued that the contract did not authorize 
  APAC to rebuild, repair, or maintain the shoulder area.Â  Instead, the contract 
  required only that the shoulder area, and particularly areas with surrounding 
  vegetation, be left in a â€œneat and presentable condition.â€Â  But because vegetation 
  did not exist in the area where the accident occurred, APAC argued that it complied 
  with the contractâ€™s mandate.Â  In addition, APAC described the eleven to twelve 
  inch resulting drop-off as a â€œpatent and obvious defect,â€ which SCDOT should 
  have noticed upon inspecting the completed work.Â  Finally, APAC argued that 
  once SCDOT accepted the resurfacing work, APAC was no longer in control of the 
  roadway and therefore no longer liable for injuries caused by the drop-off. 

In response to APACâ€™s motion for summary judgment, Dorrell 
  filed the affidavit of her expert, Peter S. Parsonson, Ph.D, P.E. (Parsonson), 
  who holds a doctorate in engineering and is a licensed professional engineer.Â  
  In his affidavit, Parsonson directly contravened APACâ€™s interpretation of the 
  contract terms and opined that APAC was responsible for the roadway condition 
  at the time of the accident.Â  Further, Parsonson described the eleven to twelve 
  inch drop as an â€œintolerable and gross defect,â€ which constituted a â€œwell-known, 
  clear, immediate, and compelling danger to the motoring public.â€Â  In his opinion, 
  by claiming that it was responsible only for one edge of the pavement to the 
  other, APAC defined the scope of its responsibility under the contract too narrowly.Â  
  Given the conflicting evidence concerning the scope of APACâ€™s responsibility 
  under the contract, the trial judge denied APACâ€™s motion for summary judgment.
Two months before trial, APAC filed a second summary judgment 
  motion, reiterating the arguments in its initial motion and including two additional 
  pieces of evidence: the deposition testimony of expert Parsonson and SCDOTâ€™s 
  responses to APACâ€™s requests for admission.Â  Based on this new evidence, the 
  trial judgeâ€”who was not the same judge who heard APACâ€™s initial motionâ€”granted 
  summary judgment to APAC, finding that (1) rebuilding, repairing, or maintaining 
  the highway shoulders was not within the scope of APACâ€™s responsibility under 
  the contract; (2) APACâ€™s work had been completed and accepted as of November 
  17, 1995; and therefore (3) SCDOT was solely responsible for the roadway and 
  shoulders at the time of the accident.Â  Additionally, the trial judge found 
  that â€œAPAC did not breach any duty to the plaintiffs which proximately caused 
  the accident.â€     Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Dorrell appeals the granting of summary judgment, asking 
  this Court to consider the following issues: 

  
    
      
         I.  
         
  Did the contract between SCDOT and APAC limit APACâ€™s liability for negligent 
  injury to third parties?
      
      
         II. 
         
  Was the defense of completion and acceptance a valid legal basis for granting 
  summary judgment?
      
      
         III. 
         
  Was it an abuse of discretion for the trial judge to hear APACâ€™s renewed motion 
  for summary judgment and use SCDOTâ€™s admissions against APAC?
      
    
  

    Law/Analysis
In reviewing a grant of summary judgment, this 
  Court must find summary judgment proper when there is no genuine issue as to 
  any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of 
  law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Osborne v. Adams, 364 S.C. 4, 550 S.E.2d 319 
  (2001).Â  In reviewing the record, the evidence must be considered in the light 
  most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. (citing Summer v. Carpenter, 
  328 S.C. 36, 492 S.E.2d 55 (1997)).
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  APACâ€™s Liability to Third Parties
Dorrell argues that the APAC-SCDOT contract does not limit 
  APACâ€™s liability for negligent injury to third parties.Â  We agree.
A tortfeasor may be liable for injury to a third party arising 
  out of the tortfeasorâ€™s contractual relationship with another, despite the absence 
  of privity between the tortfeasor and the third party.Â  Barker v. Sauls, 
  289 S.C. 121, 122, 345 S.E.2d 244, 244 (1986) (citing Terlinde v. J.F. Neely, 
  275 S.C 395, 399, 271 S.E.2d 768, 770 (1980)).Â  The tortfeasorâ€™s liability exists 
  independently of the contract and rests upon the tortfeasorâ€™s duty to exercise 
  due care.Â  Id. (citing Edwardâ€™s of Byrnes Downs v. Charleston Sheet 
  Metal Co., 253 S.C. 537, 542, 172 S.E.2d 120, 122 (1970)).Â  This common 
  law duty of due care includes the duty to avoid damage or injury to foreseeable 
  plaintiffs.Â  See Terlinde, 275 S.C. at 399, 271 S.E.2d at 770 (stating 
  that the â€œkey inquiryâ€ in determining whether to impose liability is â€œforeseeability, 
  not privityâ€).Â Â Â Â  
In a negligence action, a plaintiff must show that the (1) 
  defendant owed a duty of care to the plaintiff, (2) defendant breached the duty 
  by a negligent act or omission, (3) defendantâ€™s breach was the actual and proximate 
  cause of the plaintiffâ€™s injury, and (4) plaintiff suffered an injury or damages.Â  
  Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Reg., 336 S.C. 
  373, 387, 520 S.E.2d 142, 149 (1999) (citations omitted).Â  The Court must determine, 
  as a matter of law, whether the defendant owed a duty of care to the plaintiff.Â Â  
  Id.Â  
In the present case, we hold that APAC owed a duty 
  of care to the plaintiff, Dorrell, based on (1) the contractual relationship 
  between APAC and SCDOT and (2) a common law duty of care.Â  
APACâ€™s broad duty to the traveling public is established 
  in at least two separate provisions of the contract.Â  First, the section of 
  the contract titled â€œRequired Contract Provisions Federal-Aid Construction Contractsâ€ 
  under the heading â€œSafety: Accident Preventionâ€ states, in part, the following:

The contractor shall provide all safeguards, safety devices 
  and protective equipment and take any other needed actions as it determines 
  â€¦ to be reasonably necessary to protect the life and health of employees on 
  the job and the safety of the public â€¦.

Second, the Red Book, [2]  which is part of the contract, 
  includes the following mandate: 

107.09 Public Convenience and Safety.Â  The Contractor 
  shall at all times conduct work in such a manner as to provide for and insure 
  the safety and convenience of the traveling public â€¦.

We also note that under the contract, the work was to â€œbe 
  done in accordance with the Specifications and in a good and workmanlike manner.â€Â  
  Therefore, based on the plain language of the contract, APAC had a duty to provide 
  for the safety of the traveling public and to perform the work in a â€œworkmanlike 
  manner.â€Â  This duty arises out of APACâ€™s contractual relationship with SCDOT, 
  and the absence of privity between APAC and motorists such as Dorrell does not 
  eliminate this duty.
In addition to its duties under the contract, APAC 
  owed a common law duty to exercise due care, which existed independently of 
  the contract with SCDOT.Â  See Kennedy v. Columbia Lumber and Mfg. Co., 
  299 S.C. 335, 346, 384 S.E.2d 730, 737 (1989) (finding a homebuilder owes a 
  legal duty â€œto refrain from constructing housing that he knows or should know 
  will pose serious risks of physical harm to foreseeable partiesâ€); Smith 
  v. Fitton and Pittman, Inc., 264 S.C. 129, 133, 212 S.E.2d 925, 926 (1975) 
  (finding that an independent contractor had a duty of care to leave the premises 
  in a safe condition, free from any hazards to safety that he may have created); 
  Rogers v. Scyphers, 251 S.C. 128, 133, 161 S.E.2d 81, 84 (1968) (finding 
  a building contractor owed a duty of reasonable care that extended to homebuyers 
  and members of the buyerâ€™s family); McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 
  325 S.C. 327, 345, 479 S.E.2d 67, 76 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating that it was proper 
  for the trial judge to charge the jury with the elements of common law negligence 
  to determine whether a paving company negligently performed its work, indicating 
  that the paving company owed a duty of care based in common law); St. Clair 
  v. B.L. Paving Co., 411 A.2d 525, 526 (Pa. Super. 1979) (finding that a 
  paving company, which left a road surface six inches about the shoulder, â€œowed 
  a duty to third persons over and above compliance with the contract provisionsâ€).Â  
  This duty of care included, at minimum, a duty to pave the road in a manner 
  that provided for the safety of the traveling public, including Dorrell.Â Â Â  

Moreover, at oral argument before this Court, APACâ€™s counsel 
  explained that, in the area where the accident occurred, the road surface was 
  already nine inches above the shoulder.Â  Knowing this, APAC proceeded to lay 
  the asphalt, adding another three inches, and increasing the drop to approximately 
  twelve inches.Â  These facts alone create a jury question as to whether APAC 
  breached its duty of care.Â Â Â  
Accordingly, we hold that the APAC-SCDOT contract did not 
  limit APACâ€™s liability for negligent injury to third parties.Â  Like all motorists 
  that traveled the stretch of highway recently repaved by APAC, Dorrell was a 
  foreseeable plaintiff, and APACâ€™s duties to Dorrell stemmed from both the APAC-SCDOT 
  contract and the common law.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Completion and Acceptance
Dorrell argues that the completion and acceptance 
  defense was not a valid legal basis for granting summary judgment.Â  We agree.
Historically, this Court has found that a contractor 
  is not liable to third parties who have been injured as a result of negligent 
  construction after the work has been completed and accepted by the other party 
  to the contract or the owner.Â  Clyde v. Sumerel, 233 S.C. 228, 232-33, 
  104 S.E.2d 392, 393 (1958); see also Nichols v. Craven, 224 S.C. 244, 
  78 S.E.2d 376 (1953) (holding that a paving company was not liable for failing 
  to place appropriate signs and barricades at construction site once the paving 
  companyâ€™s work was completed and accepted and the highway department regained 
  sole responsibility for traffic flow).Â  Under this basic rule of tort law, which 
  is commonly referred to as the â€œcompleted and accepted ruleâ€ or â€œacceptance 
  rule,â€ a contractorâ€™s liability ceases upon a showing that the completed work 
  has been practically, not necessarily formally, accepted.Â  Id.  
But as early as 1968, the completion and acceptance 
  defense began to fall out of favor in South Carolina.Â  In Rogers v. Scyphers, 
  this Court refused to allow a building contractor to use the defense to avoid 
  liability for an injury caused when the plaintiff fell on a negligently constructed 
  stairway.Â  251 S.C. at 133, 161 S.E.2d at 84.Â  The Court stated:Â  

the entire weight of modern authority is to the effect that 
  building contractors â€¦ are liable for injuries to, or the death of, third persons 
  occurring after the completion of the work and acceptance by the owner, where 
  the work is reasonably certain to endanger third persons if negligently prepared 
  or constructed.

251 S.C. at 132, 161 S.E.2d at 83.Â  Moreover, the 
  Court noted that â€œwe see no rational difference between the duty owed by the 
  manufacturer of a chattel and the duty owed by the builder-vendor of a new structure.â€Â  
  Id. at 134, 161 S.E.2d at 84.Â  Accordingly, â€œthere was a duty on the 
  defendants as builders to use reasonable care in the construction of the home 
  to avoid unreasonable risk and danger to those who would normally occupy it 
  â€¦.â€Â  Id.Â  Therefore, the Court held that the defendantsâ€™ motion to dismiss 
  was properly overruled. [3] Â  
  Id. at 137, 161 S.E.2d at 85.
Later, in 1975, this Court affirmed judgment for a 
  person injured from falling into a six-foot-deep hole left by a contractor for 
  the telephone company, who had removed a telephone pole earlier that day.Â  Smith 
  v. Fitton and Pittman, Inc., 264 S.C. 129, 133, 212 S.E.2d 925, 926 (1975).Â  
  Because the contractor had a duty of care to leave the premises in a safe condition, 
  the Court held that the issue of negligence was properly submitted to the jury.Â  
  Id.Â  
After affirming judgment for the injured plaintiff, 
  the Court addressed the issue of whether the contractor could be relieved of 
  liability based on the theory that the work had been completed and accepted.Â  
  The Court explained that â€œ[t]o the extent that this doctrine has not been eroded 
  by Rogers, it is still viable.â€Â  Id. at 134, 212 S.E.2d at 926; 
  see also Henderson v. St. Francis Hosp., 295 S.C. 441, 369 S.E.2d 652 
  (Ct. App. 1988), reversed on other grounds, 303 S.C. 177, 399 S.E.2d 
  767 (1990) (holding that the designer of a parking lot was not liable to a plaintiff 
  who fell on a sweetgum ball in the lot, given that the lot was designed sixteen 
  years before the fall and the defects were neither latent nor concealed).Â  Though 
  viable, the Court found that the doctrine was not available as a defense in 
  this case because the person who â€œacceptedâ€ the work did not have the â€œactual 
  or apparent authority to do so.â€Â  Id.Â  Apparently the contractors had 
  planned to refill the hole, but an employee from the business occupying the 
  property told the contractors to straddle the hole with the removed pole instead.Â  
  The Court found the employeeâ€™s instruction did not constitute acceptance, and 
  the telephone company, as the contracting party, was the appropriate person 
  to accept the completed work.Â  Therefore, the doctrine did not relieve the contractor 
  of liability.Â  Id. at 134, 212 S.E.2d at 927.Â  
Although Smith suggested that the completion 
  and acceptance doctrine, though eroded, remained viable, South Carolina courts 
  have continued to limit its application.Â  For example, the South Carolina Court 
  of Appeals has explicitly refused to apply the doctrine in products liability 
  cases, finding that the application of the doctrine â€œwould undermine the whole 
  concept of products liability.â€Â  Stanley v. Montague Co., Inc., 299 S.C. 
  51, 54, 382 S.E.2d 246, 248 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  In addition to finding that the 
  doctrine did not apply in the products context, the court in Stanley 
  addressed the doctrineâ€™s overall demise.Â  The court noted that â€œ[p]rinciples 
  governing the liability of contractors for injuries to third parties have followed 
  principles governing the liability of manufacturers for injuries to persons 
  not in privity with the manufacturers.â€Â  Id. at 52, 382 S.E.2d at 247.Â  
  In fact, the court read Rogers v. Scyphers as a case that â€œspecifically 
  repudiatedâ€ the doctrine.Â  Id. at 55, 382 S.E.2d at 248.Â  Consequently, 
  the Stanley court concluded, â€œthe defense of completion and acceptance, 
  like the defense of lack of privity, has fallen into disfavor in South Carolina.â€Â  
  Id. at 56, 382 S.E.2d at 249.Â Â Â  
South Carolina has not been alone in disfavoring 
  the completion and acceptance doctrine.Â  

As late as the 1950s, the majority of jurisdictions adhered 
  to the â€œcompleted and accepted rule.â€Â  Since then, the â€œcompleted and accepted 
  ruleâ€ has been severely criticized and repudiated in most states and is now 
  the minority rule while the â€œmodern ruleâ€ has become the majority rule.

Emmanuel S. Tipon, Modern Status of Rules Regarding 
  Tort Liability of Building or Construction Contractor for Injury or Damage to 
  Third Person Occurring After Completion and Acceptance of Work; â€œForeseeabilityâ€ 
  or â€œModernâ€ Rule, 75 A.L.R.5th 413, 437 (2000). 
  [4] Â  The modern rule, or â€œforeseeability doctrine,â€ may be stated in the 
  following way:

A building or construction contractor is liable for injury 
  or damage to a third person even after completion of the work and its acceptance 
  by the owner where it was reasonably foreseeable that a third person would be 
  injured by such work on account of the contractorâ€™s negligence or failure to 
  disclose a dangerous condition known to such contractor.

Id. at 436.Â  The rule has been applied in 
  multiple contexts, including cases involving the construction of streets and 
  highways.Â  Id. at 534-35; see also Louk v. Isuzu Motors, Inc., 
  479 S.E.2d 911, 921 (W. Va. 1996) (a highway engineer may be held liable for 
  negligence even after the highway plan or design has been accepted and the highway 
  constructed according to the plan); McFadden v. Ten-T Corp., 529 So.2d 
  192, 200 (Ala. 1988) (paving contractor may be liable for creating a hazardous 
  condition during resurfacing and widening of highway several months after project 
  completed and accepted by highway department); Johnson v. Oman Constr. Co., 
  Inc., 519 S.W.2d 782, 788 (Tenn. 1975) (an independent contractor who left 
  a barricadeâ€”which was not striped, painted, or illuminatedâ€”on a highway may 
  be held liable for negligence even after project completed and accepted).Â Â  

The modern view, rejecting the completion 
  and acceptance doctrine, is reflected in the Restatement (Second) of Torts as 
  well:

One who on behalf of the possessor of land erects a structure 
  or creates any other condition thereon is subject to liability to others upon 
  or outside of the land for physical harm caused to them by the dangerous character 
  of the structure or condition after his work has been accepted by the possessor, 
  under the same rules as those determining the liability of one who as manufacturer 
  or independent contractor makes a chattel for the use of others.

Restatement (Second) of Torts, Â§ 385 (1965).Â  

South Carolina cases that have considered and rejected 
  the application of the completion and acceptance doctrine have incorporated 
  foreseeability of harm in the analysis.Â  For example, in Smith v. Fitton, 
  the Court explained that given the location of the six-foot-deep hole left by 
  the contractor who removed the telephone pole, â€œit was certainly inferable that 
  this area would be traversed by invitees as well as the owner.â€Â  264 S.C. at 
  133, 212 S.E.2d at 926.Â  Additionally, in Rogers v. Scyphers, the Court 
  stated that contractors are liable, even after completion and acceptance of 
  the work, â€œwhere the work is reasonably certain to endanger third persons if 
  negligently prepared or constructed.â€Â  251 S.C. at 132, 161 S.E.2d at 83; see 
  also Prosser and Keeton on Torts Â§ 104A, 723 (5th ed. 1984) (citing 
  Rogers v. Scyphers and stating â€œ[i]t is now the almost universal rule 
  that the contractor is liable to all those who may foreseeably be injured by 
  the structure, not only when he fails to disclose dangerous conditions known 
  to him, but also when the work is negligently done.â€). 
We join the majority of jurisdictions in deciding 
  that a contractorâ€™s duty of care is not extinguished upon the completion and 
  acceptance of the contractorâ€™s work.Â  Liability should be governed by the same 
  principles that govern ordinary negligence actions, and we see no reason why 
  paving contractors should be treated differently from building contractors and 
  product manufacturers.Â  
Therefore, in light of Rogers and its progeny, 
  the completion and acceptance defense was an improper legal basis upon which 
  to grant summary judgment.Â  APAC cannot escape liability simply by completing 
  its work and having it accepted by SCDOT.Â  APAC had a duty of care that extended 
  above and beyond compliance with the contract, and whether APAC breached that 
  duty of care is a question of fact that must be decided by a jury.Â  Moreover, 
  it is for a jury to decide whether Dorrellâ€™s injury was foreseeable.Â  Therefore, 
  the trial courtâ€™s decision granting summary judgment is reversed.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
III.Â Â Â  Abuse of Discretion
Dorrell argues that the trial judge abused his 
  discretion by (1) hearing APACâ€™s renewed motion for summary judgment and (2) 
  using SCDOTâ€™s admissions against APAC.Â  We disagree.
The trial judge had the discretionary authority 
  to hear APACâ€™s renewed motion for summary judgment.Â  That a different trial 
  judge previously denied the motion did not preclude APAC from renewing its motion 
  once new evidence came to light.Â  See Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 
  S.C. 476, 477, 443 S.E.2d 379, 380 (1994) (citations omitted) (finding that 
  a denial of a motion for summary judgment does not affect the merits of the 
  case and simply indicates that the case should proceed to trial).Â  Further, 
  â€œif the first motion for summary judgment is unsuccessful the court has the 
  power to permit a second motion for summary judgment prior to trial.â€Â  Croswell 
  Enter., Inc. v. Arnold, 309 S.C. 276, 279, 422 S.E.2d 157, 159 (Ct. App. 
  1992).
As to SCDOTâ€™s admissions, the trial judge had the 
  discretion to consider the impact of these admissions just as he would any other 
  evidence.Â  Moreover, the trial judge had the discretion to allow such evidence 
  to be admitted outside of the scheduling order.Â  Accordingly, the trial judge 
  did not abuse his discretion.  
Conclusion
Based on the foregoing analysis, we reverse 
  the order granting summary judgment and remand this case for a jury trial in 
  accordance with this opinion.Â Â Â Â  
 MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  A third defendant, APAC-Georgia, Inc., was dismissed by stipulation.

 
   
    [2]  â€œRed Bookâ€ is the common name for the â€œSouth Carolina State Highway 
    Department Standard Specifications for Highway Construction,â€ which is typically 
    incorporated into highway construction contracts. The 1986 edition of the 
    Red Book was part of the contract in this case.

 
   
    [3]  In so holding, the Court â€œassumed that the defect in the stairway 
    was a latent, concealed one, unknown to plaintiff or her husband prior to 
    plaintiffâ€™s injury â€¦.â€ Â Id.Â  

 
   
    [4]  We note that this A.L.R. section supersedes the section relied upon 
    by the Court in Clyde v. Sumerel and Nichols v. Craven.

BENCH MEMORANDUM


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
E'Van Frazier, Respondent,
v.
Athaniel Badger, Jr., Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF
CERTIORARI

Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25876
Heard January 6, 2004 - Filed September 
  27, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Andrea E. White, of Duff, Turner, White and Boykin, 
  LLC, and Andrew F. Lindemann, of Davidson, Morrison and Lindemann, P.A., both 
  of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Lawrence Keitt, of Keitt and Associates, of Orangeburg, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This 
  review stems from an action by Eâ€™Van Frazier (â€œFrazierâ€) against Athaniel Badger, 
  Jr. (â€œBadgerâ€) for the tort of outrage.Â  The jury awarded Frazier $400,000 in 
  actual damages and $400,000 in punitive damages.Â  The trial judge reduced the 
  award to $200,000 in actual damages and $200,000 in punitive damages.Â  The Court 
  of Appeals affirmed in an unpublished opinion.Â  Frazier v. Badger, Op. 
  No. 2002-UP-513 (Ct. App., filed August 20, 2002).Â  We granted certiorari and 
  affirm the Court of Appeals.
Factual/Procedural BackgroundÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
During the 1995-96 school year, 
  Frazier was employed to supervise the in-school suspension lab at Clark Middle 
  School.Â  At that time, Badger was the assistant principal of Clark Middle School 
  and was Frazierâ€™s direct supervisor.Â  Around the beginning of the school year, 
  Badger began visiting Frazierâ€™s classroom and making explicit, sexual advances 
  towards her.Â  When Frazier refused Badgerâ€™s propositions, he told her that eventually 
  he was going to â€œbreak her.â€Â  As the school year progressed, Badgerâ€™s visits 
  became more frequent, and his advances became physical.Â  Frazier testified that 
  Badger would grab her legs and breasts and that she had to â€œfight him offâ€ of 
  her on several occasions.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
As part of Badgerâ€™s duties as 
  assistant principal, he received requests for building repairs.Â  Frazier repeatedly 
  asked Badger to send someone to repair the heating and air conditioning in her 
  classroom.Â  Despite Badgerâ€™s promises, the heating and air conditioning were 
  never repaired.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
At the end of the school year, 
  Badger told Frazier that if she came back to work in the fall, he would move 
  her class into a portion of the basement known as the â€œdungeon.â€Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
As a result of Badgerâ€™s behavior, 
  Frazier suffered emotionally and physically.Â  She became severely depressed.Â  
  Her weight plummeted below 100 pounds, and she began having anxiety attacks 
  and losing her hair.Â  Her physician referred her to a psychiatrist who proscribed 
  her medication for depression and insomnia.Â  Frazier also testified that her 
  fiancÃ© left her because of her emotional condition.Â Â  
On August 1, 1996, Frazier 
  wrote Priscilla Robinson (â€œRobinsonâ€), Principal of Clark Middle School, about 
  Badgerâ€™s conduct, which led to a meeting between Robinson, Badger, and Frazier.Â  
  After the meeting, Robinson wrote Frazier a letter acknowledging that Badger 
  had admitted to and apologized for making inappropriate comments.Â  She also 
  wrote in her letter that it appeared that Badger had submitted work orders for 
  the heating and air conditioning.Â  
Frazier wrote Robinson 
  another letter because she was dissatisfied with the investigation.Â  As a result, 
  District Superintendent, Dr. Walter Tobin assigned three people to investigate 
  the matter further.Â  The investigators found that (1) Badger made inappropriate 
  comments to Frazier; (2) Badger sent Frazierâ€™s requests to the maintenance department, 
  requesting that the heating and air conditioning be repaired, but the units 
  were not repaired in a timely manner; and (3) Robinson, not Badger, decided 
  to move Frazier into the â€œdungeon.â€
At the beginning of the 
  next school year, Frazierâ€™s class was relocated to the basement, and she was 
  told that her old classroom would be used for a computer lab. 
  [1] Â  Robinson also told Frazier that until her downstairs classroom was 
  ready for use, her classroom would be located on the cafeteria stage.Â  This 
  temporary location made Frazierâ€™s job increasingly difficult.Â  Though the stage 
  curtains were drawn, Frazier had a hard time keeping the students in class.Â  
  It was only after Frazier filed a complaint with the Department of Human Affairs 
  that Frazier was given a regular classroom. 
At trial, Badger testified 
  that he was Frazierâ€™s basketball coach fifteen years ago, and that their relationship 
  was â€œplayful.â€Â  He admitted to making inappropriate remarks and inviting her 
  to dinner, but he denied making sexually explicit comments or grabbing her.Â  
  He also testified that he did not recall refusing to process any work orders 
  to repair the heating and air conditioning in Frazierâ€™s classroom.Â  Finally, 
  he denied that he ever threatened to relocate Frazierâ€™s classroom to the basement.
The jury found that Badgerâ€™s 
  sexual advances towards Frazier, combined with his retaliatory conduct, met 
  the elements for the tort of outrage.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed the trial 
  courtâ€™s ruling in an unpublished opinion.Â  Frazier v. Badger, Op. No. 
  2002-UP-513 (Ct. App., filed August 20, 2002).Â  Badger now presents the following 
  issues for review on certiorari:

  
    
      
        I.
         Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s refusal 
  to charge the jury on the law of tort immunity for government employees?
      
      
        II.
        Did the
          Court of Appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of the
          motion for mistrial?
      
      
        III.  
        Did the
          Court of Appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s ruling that
          Frazier was not barred from bringing an outrage action in lieu of an
          action for sexual harassment?
      
      
         IV. 
         
  Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s refusal to submit 
  special interrogatories to the jury?
      
      
         V.
         
  Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the punitive damages award?
      
    
  

    Law/Analysis
I. Governmental Immunity
Badger argues that he is immune 
  from tort actions stemming from conduct within the scope of his official duties 
  pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann. section 15-78-70 (Supp. 2003), [2]  and therefore the trial court abused its discretion 
  when it refused to charge the jury on the law concerning immunity.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Code Ann. section 
  15-78-70 specifically provides that government employees may be liable in tort 
  actions:

  (a)           
  This chapter constitutes the exclusive remedy for any tort committed by an employee 
  of a governmental entity.Â  An employee of a governmental entity who commits 
  a tort while acting within the scope of his official duty is not liable 
  therefor except as expressly provided for in subsection (b).
  (b)           
  Nothing in this chapter may be construed to give an employee of a governmental 
  entity immunity from suit and liability if it is proved that the employeeâ€™s 
  conduct was not within the scope of his official duties or that it constituted 
  actual fraud, actual malice, intent to harm, or a crime involving moral turpitude.
â€¦

(Emphasis added).
Immunity under the statute is 
  an affirmative defense that must be proved by the defendant at trial.Â  Tanner 
  v. Florence City-County Bldg. Commâ€™n, 333 S.C. 549, 552, 511 S.E.2d 
  369, 371 (Ct. App. 1999).
The trial judge is required to 
  charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina. Cohens v. Atkins, 
  333 S.C. 345, 509 S.E.2d 286 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The law to be charged to the 
  jury is determined by the evidence at trial. State v. Hill, 315 S.C. 
  260, 262, 433 S.E.2d 848, 849 (1993).Â  In reviewing jury charges for error, 
  appellate courts must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence 
  and issues presented at trial.Â  Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. 
  Sys., 334 S.C. 488, 497, 514 S.E.2d 570, 574 (1999).Â  
This Court has held that the 
  term â€œscope of employmentâ€ as used in an insurance policy is broader than the 
  term â€œscope of official dutiesâ€ as used in the Tort Claims Act.Â  South Carolina 
  State Budget and Control Bd. v. Prince, 304 S.C. 241, 245, 403 S.E.2d 
  643, 646 (1991).Â  IfÂ  â€œscope of employmentâ€ is a broader term than â€œscope of 
  official dutiesâ€ - the term used in the governmental immunity statute - it follows 
  that acts not within the â€œscope of employmentâ€ are not within the â€œscope of 
  official duties.â€
We recognize that whether an 
  act is within the â€œscope of employmentâ€ may be determined by implication from 
  the circumstances of a particular case.Â  Hamilton v. Miller, 301 S.C. 
  45, 48, 389 S.E.2d 652, 653 (1990); Wade v. Berkeley County, 330 S.C. 
  311, 319, 498 S.E.2d 684, 688 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In Prince, we held that 
  the course of someoneâ€™s employment requires some â€œact in furtherance of the 
  employerâ€™s business.â€ 304 S.C. at 246, 403 S.E.2d at 647.
Our jurisprudence includes three 
  cases that consider whether sexual advances were within the â€œscope of an employeeâ€™s 
  employment.â€Â  Because the cases did not relate to governmental immunity, the 
  court of appeals declined to apply them.Â  Nonetheless, we find that â€œscope of 
  employmentâ€ is a term of art, and therefore we look to the cases involving insurance 
  policies for guidance.
In the first case, this Court 
  held that a police officerâ€™s sexual assaults of women during traffic stops were 
  not within the scope of his official duties, and therefore the acts were not 
  covered under the stateâ€™s general tort liability policy. Doe v. South Carolina 
  State Budget and Control Bd., 337 S.C. 294, 523 S.E.2d 457 (1999).Â  In the 
  second case, the court of appeals held that a professor was not acting within 
  the scope of his employment when he sexually harassed a student.Â  Therefore, 
  the professorâ€™s conduct was not covered under the universityâ€™s liability insurance 
  policy.Â  Padgett v. South Carolina Ins. Reserve Fund, 340 S.C. 250, 253, 
  531 S.E.2d 305, 307 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In the third case, the court of appeals 
  held that a sheriffâ€™s sexual advances toward three of his female officers was 
  not within the scope of the sheriffâ€™s official duties.Â  Loadholt v. S.C. 
  State Budget and Control Bd., 339 S.C. 165, 528 S.E.2d 670 (Ct. App. 2000).
According to these cases, sexual 
  harassment by a government employee is not within the employeeâ€™s â€œscope of employment.â€Â  
  Therefore, in the present case, we hold that Badgerâ€™s sexual advances toward 
  Frazier were outside the scope of his official duties or employment.Â  
The more difficult question is 
  whether Badgerâ€™s retaliatory conduct was within the scope of his official 
  duties or employment.Â  Under the particular circumstances of this case, we find 
  no evidence that any of Badgerâ€™s retaliatory conduct was done in furtherance 
  of his employerâ€™s business.Â  This is not to say that a jury charge on the law 
  of governmental immunity is inappropriate in every case where allegations are 
  made against a governmental official for retaliatory conduct.Â  What a plaintiff 
  may call â€œretaliatory conductâ€ may be justified by some independent employer 
  interest, warranting a charge on governmental immunity.Â  We find Badgerâ€™s moving 
  Frazierâ€™s class to the schoolâ€™s stage and basement furthered none of the schoolâ€™s 
  legitimate interests because Frazierâ€™s old classroom was left unused.Â  In addition, 
  none of the schoolâ€™s legitimate interests were furthered by Badgerâ€™s failure 
  to repair Frazierâ€™s air and heating unit or Badgerâ€™s repeated threats to fire 
  Frazier.Â  
We find that Badgerâ€™s retaliatory 
  conduct was a continuation of his improper sexual advances toward Frazier and 
  was a product of personal, not occupational, motives.Â  The principle of governmental 
  immunity is not intended to protect a defendant such as Badger who has used 
  his authority for nothing more than to personally retaliate against an employee.Â  
  In addition, section 15-78-70(b) denies governmental immunity for defendants 
  whose actions involve actual malice and an intent to harm.Â  We find that Badgerâ€™s 
  retaliatory conduct involved actual malice and an intention to harm Frazier.
Accordingly, we hold that the 
  trial judge did not err in rejecting Badgerâ€™s request to charge the jury on 
  the defense of governmental immunity because the evidence did not support such 
  a charge.
II. Motion For Mistrial
At pretrial, the trial judge 
  granted a motion in limine excluding evidence of Badgerâ€™s alleged attempted 
  rape of Frazier approximately fifteen years ago.Â  At trial, Badger testified 
  that he and Frazier had a â€œplayfulâ€ relationship when he coached her in basketball.Â  
  When Frazier took the stand, she testified that Badger began making sexual advances 
  toward her when he was her high school basketball coach.Â  Badger argues that 
  this evidence was inadmissible, and thus the trial judge should have granted 
  his motion for mistrial.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
A litigant cannot complain of 
  prejudice by reason of an issue he has placed before the court.Â  See State 
  v. Brown, 344 S.C. 70, 543 S.E.2d. 552 (2001) (petitioner cannot complain 
  of prejudice from evidence he has brought before the jury); State v. Robinson, 
  305 S.C. 469, 409 S.E.2d. 404 (1991) (a party will be unsuccessful in opposing 
  the admission of evidence if that party was the one who opened the door).Â  
Whether a motion for mistrial 
  should be granted is within the trial judgeâ€™s sound discretion, and the trial 
  judgeâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed unless an abuse of discretion is shown.Â  
  Tucker v. Reynolds, 268 S.C. 330, 334, 233 S.E.2d. 402, 404 (1977).
Badger, not Frazier, first testified 
  that he and Frazier had a â€œplayfulâ€ relationship when he was her basketball 
  coach.Â  Once Badger introduced the nature of the relationship, he opened the 
  door, allowing Frazier to testify as to her perspective of the past relationship.Â  
  According to Brown, Frazierâ€™s testimony was admissible and non-prejudicial 
  since Badger himself introduced the matter.Â  Therefore, we find that Badgerâ€™s 
  motion for mistrial was properly denied.
III.Â  Outrage in lieu of Sexual HarassmentÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Badger argues that Frazier should 
  have brought a claim against Badger for sexual harassment, not the tort of outrage, 
  citing Todd v. South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 283 S.C. 155, 
  175, 321 S.E.2d 602, 613 (Ct. App. 1984), quashed on other grounds, 287 
  S.C. 190, 336 S.E.2d 472 (1985), in which this Court held:Â  â€œ[t]he tort of outrage 
  was designed not as a replacement for the existing tort actions.Â  Rather, it 
  was conceived as a remedy for tortious conduct where no remedy previously existed.â€Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

We recognize that Frazier had 
  a statutory right to file a civil rights complaint against Badger for sexual 
  harassment.Â  However, because this is a right created by statute and not the 
  common law of torts, we find no reason to restrict Frazierâ€™s right to sue Badger 
  based upon the common law tort of outrage.
IV. Special Interrogatories
Badger argues that the Court 
  of Appeals erred in affirming the trial judgeâ€™s denial of his request to submit 
  special interrogatories to the jury.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The trial judge has the discretion 
  to determine whether to submit special interrogatories.Â  Rule 49(b) SCRCP; Constant 
  v. Spartanburg Steel Products, Inc., 316 S.C. 86, 90, 447 S.E.2d 194, 196 
  (1994).Â  To warrant a reversal, a party must show that he was prejudiced by 
  the trial courtâ€™s refusal to submit special interrogatories.Â  Steele v. Dillard, 
  327 S.C. 340, 343, 486 S.E.2d 278, 279-80 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In Anderson v. 
  West, this Court held â€œthat where a jury returns a general verdict involving 
  two or more issues and its verdict is supported as to at least one issue, the 
  verdict will not be reversed.â€ 270 S.C. 184, 188, 241 S.E.2d 551, 553 (1978).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Here, Badger requested that the 
  trial judge require the jury to make specific findings of fact as to Frazierâ€™s 
  allegations of Badgerâ€™s sexual misconduct and retaliation.Â  Instead, the trial 
  judge gave a general jury charge on the tort of outrage.Â  
We agree with the Court of Appealsâ€™ analysis on this issue: 


[t]here was no need to submit 
  special interrogatories to the jury for specific findings of fact, as the two 
  parts of her claim cannot be compartmentalized.Â  As Frazierâ€™s only claim before 
  the jury was that of outrage, the jury would have simply found for Badger if 
  the jurors believed the elements of outrage had been met.

Frazier v. Badger, Op. 
  No. 2002-UP-513, page 6 (Ct. App., filed August 20, 2002).
Badger was unable to show that 
  he suffered prejudice from the trial judgeâ€™s general jury charge on outrage.Â Â  
  Further, we find no reason to believe that the jury misunderstood the trial 
  judgeâ€™s charge on outrage and recognize the existence of evidence warranting 
  Frazierâ€™s recovery on this claim.Â  Therefore, we hold that the trial judge did 
  not abuse his discretion in denying Badgerâ€™s request to submit special interrogatories 
  to the jury.
V. Excessive Punitive 
  DamagesÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Badger argues that the Court 
  of Appeals erred in upholding the juryâ€™s punitive damage award because Frazier 
  failed to introduce evidence of Badgerâ€™s ability to pay, which he argues is 
  the most important factor in a constitutional review of an award of punitive 
  damages.Â  We disagree.
First, a defendantâ€™s inability 
  to pay does not prohibit a jury from awarding punitive damages.Â  In Gamble 
  v. Stevenson, this Court established eight factors for a trial court to 
  apply in a post-verdict review of punitive damages.Â  305 S.C. 104, 111, 406 
  S.E.2d 350, 354 (1991).Â  The ability of the defendant to pay the punitive damages 
  awarded is only one of eight factors.Â  As part of its holding in Gamble, 
  this Court opined, â€œthe trial court shall conduct a post-trial review 
  and may consider the followingâ€¦â€ Id. (emphasis added).Â  The word 
  â€œmayâ€ signifies that the Gamble factors are to provide guidance, not 
  â€œhard and fastâ€ requirements.Â  Further, â€œpost-trialâ€ signifies that the Gamble 
  factors are to be applied after a verdict, by the judge, not the jury.
Second, this Court has consistently 
  held that an award of punitive damages will not be overturned because a defendant 
  is unable to pay. While a defendantâ€™s wealth is a relevant factor in assessing 
  punitive damages, it is not necessarily controlling.Â  Hicks v. Herring, 
  246 S.C. 429, 144 S.E.2d 151 (1965).Â  There is â€œno requirement that the defendant 
  be a man of means before the jury is justified in awarding punitive damages.â€Â  
  Norton v. Ewaskio, 241 S.C. 557, 565, 129 S.E.2d 517, 521 (1963).Â  A 
  jury may consider a defendantâ€™s financial worth in determining the amount of 
  punitive damages to award, but a jury is not required to make this consideration 
  before it may award punitive damages.Â  Rogers v. Florence Printing Co., 
  233 S.C. 567, 106 S.E.2d 258 (1958).Â  
Third, the United States Supreme 
  Court recently refused to include the defendantâ€™s ability to pay in its due 
  process analysis of punitive damages.Â  State Farm Mut. Ins. Co.Â  v. Campbell, 
  538 U.S. 408, 123 S. Ct. 1513, 155 L. Ed. 2d 585 (2003).Â  Instead, the Campbell 
  Court held that â€œthe most important indicium of the reasonableness of a punitive 
  damages award is the degree of reprehensibility of the defendantâ€™s conduct.â€Â  
  Id at __, 123 S. Ct. at 1521 (citing BMW of North America, Inc.Â  v. 
  Gore, 517 U.S. 559, 575, 116 S. Ct. 1589, 1598 (1996)).Â  
According to the Campbell 
  analysis, the award in this case is constitutional:Â  the award fairly reflects 
  Petitionerâ€™s reprehensibility; represents a 1 to 1 ratio to actual damages; 
  and is comparable to punitive damages awards in other cases involving the tort 
  of outrage.Â  See Campbell, 538 U.S. 408, 123 S. Ct. 1513, 155 L. Ed. 
  2d 585 (2003)(In determining the constitutionality of a punitive damages award, 
  the reviewing court must look to three guideposts: Â (1) the degree of reprehensibility 
  of the defendantâ€™s misconduct; (2) the disparity between the actual and potential 
  harm suffered by the plaintiff and the punitive damages award; and (3) the difference 
  between the punitive damages awarded by the jury and the civil penalties authorized 
  or imposed in comparable cases.) 
Therefore, the punitive damages 
  award in this case does not offend Badgerâ€™s due process.
Conclusion
We affirm the ruling of 
  the Court of Appeals, upholding the juryâ€™s award of $200,000 actual damages 
  and $200,000 punitive damages for Frazier.
 MOORE, 
  WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The school never transformed Frazierâ€™s original classroom into a 
    computer lab.

 
   
    [2]  Section 15-78-70 is a provision within the South Carolina Tort Claims 
    Act titled,Â  â€œLiability for act of government employee; requirement that agency 
    or political subdivision be named party defendant; effect of judgment or settlement.â€
